item.title: 15 must-have contact center capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
Without question, the contact center has become an integral part of the modern business. It’s where brands manage the customer experience—and through that, it’s how they compete in an increasingly consumer-first marketplace.

Therefore, contact center technology is key to making the most of every customer interaction. The only problem? Not all contact center solutions are the same. Pick the wrong one and you not only risk losing resources, but customer loyalty, too.

So, choosing a platform can make or break your success. Whether it be inbound customer inquiries or outbound calls, you need a solution that fits your specific needs. In this guide, we’ll explore the essential contact center capabilities you should consider when making this all-important decision.

Contact center capabilities you need to succeed.

1. Omnichannel support

Today’s consumers use three to five channels to interact with brands. For example, the average person switches between websites and mobile channels nearly six times before finally booking a hotel reservation.

However, maintaining a seamless customer experience across multiple channels isn’t easy. Without integration, you risk adding unnecessary friction to the process, which can frustrate and drive away consumers.

That’s why businesses need omnichannel contact center solutions. An omnichannel channel center makes customer communication more flexible, letting people choose how they interact with your brand. It allows agents to field customer inquiries no matter where they occur, whether via phone, email, live chat, social media, or SMS. Not only does this give consumers a better experience, but agents don’t have to jump between disparate channels to address customer needs.

Imagine someone engages customer support to resolve an issue. They start with a live chat, but their case requires human interaction, so they call the contact center. Rather than agents asking the caller to repeat themselves, an omnichannel solution can retain contextual customer information and display it in the agent’s dashboard. Plus, they can access historical data, like past interactions or sales histories, for further reference.

The result? A frictionless handoff between chat to phone call without skipping a beat.

2. Intelligent routing

How you distribute incoming calls and cases can significantly impact how the interaction goes. If you send callers to someone ill-equipped to handle their needs, it makes for a negative customer experience. Plus, the interaction will take longer, which makes your contact center less productive. 
Enter intelligent routing and Automatic Call Distribution (ACD). Rather than route incoming calls randomly, they use advanced techniques like artificial intelligence (AI) to streamline and optimize the process. For instance, with skill-based routing, the ACD can match customer inquiries to the most suitable contact center agents.

This minimizes the chance of a bad interaction and sets the agent up for success. If an agent is busy, Automatic Call Distribution will simply send the case to another who can handle the problem. Better yet, if someone calls back due to a dropped call, the platform can reroute them to the same agent.

Today’s AI-powered contact center solutions take intelligent routing even further. With Webex Contact Center, you can leverage channel routing that optimizes itself based on topic, customer sentiment, capacity, and agent conditions.

3. Customer journey intelligence and orchestration

Consumer expectations are constantly changing. Consider this:

  • 81% of customers prefer companies that offer a personalized experience.
  • 70% say it’s important that employees know who they are and their history with the company—past purchases, buying patterns, customer support calls, etc.

Contact center technology must evolve to meet these needs, and this is where customer journey intelligence becomes essential. By leveraging comprehensive customer data, contact center software equips agents with detailed context about each individual’s interaction history and challenges, allowing them to adopt a more informed and personalized approach.

By offering a holistic view of customer behavior—whether they abandoned a cart, faced a website issue, or previously spoke to support—agents can address issues faster and recommend solutions that fit the customer’s journey.

But why stop there? With Webex Contact Center, you can design and manage customer journeys with a low-code, no-code flow builder. That means you can map out tailored experiences and automate every step, from initial customer engagement to resolution.

For example, customers might enter through a chatbot, progress to an agent for more complex issues, and receive a follow-up survey—all seamlessly aligned with their needs and preferences. Best of all, because there’s no technical expertise required, you can do this without burdening IT resources.

4. Workforce optimization tools

Agent performance is key to customer satisfaction, but a traditional call center solution doesn’t offer nearly enough visibility for supervisors to monitor agents effectively. Fortunately, those days are over.

Now, with the right platform, quality assurance and workforce management are simple, streamlined processes. Managers can access automated call transcripts to ensure script compliance or listen live and intervene if necessary.

By monitoring and measuring agent performance, whether it be at a high level or on a granular basis, supervisors can identify potential areas of improvement to provide better customer service. Workforce optimization tools also help managers plan operations. For instance, advanced forecasting and adaptive scheduling can help ensure the contact center has an appropriately sized staff for peak demand.

Critically, managers can use artificial intelligence to pull top-rated calls automatically, allowing them to identify best practices for future training purposes.

5. Predictive dialer

A predictive dialer streamlines outbound calling, automatically dialing numbers and only connecting agents once someone answers a call. This automation significantly boosts agent productivity by reducing downtime and enabling them to focus solely on live interactions.

For contact centers that rely on proactive outreach, such as sales or collections teams, predictive dialing maximizes outbound call efficiency and drives higher customer engagement. The time savings mean agents can achieve more within their shifts, ultimately contributing to better results and a smoother customer journey.

6. Virtual agent self-service

A virtual agent is an AI-powered tool designed to interact with customers and assist with tasks through automated conversations. Equipped with natural language processing and machine learning, virtual agents can understand, interpret, and respond to customer inquiries in real time, often mimicking human conversational patterns.

Their primary use case? Customer self-service. Today’s contact center software isn’t complete without text- or voice-based self-service technology, such as:

  • Conversational AI chatbots: These virtual agents use AI to understand and address customer needs in a way that feels human, providing quick answers and solutions without waiting for a live agent. By automating routine interactions, chatbots help manage call volume, enabling agents to focus on more complex cases while offering customers a fast, convenient way to resolve common issues.
  • Interactive voice response (IVR): IVR systems guide callers through automated menus to help them reach the appropriate resources quickly. Through advanced speech recognition, these virtual agents can interpret spoken responses, route calls effectively, and answer frequently asked questions. IVR systems enhance self-service by allowing customers to resolve issues independently, thus reducing wait times and making the experience more efficient.

According to a recent Cisco survey, self-service tools are highly effective, especially for organizations that fully embrace AI:

  • Leading AI adopters saw customer satisfaction (CSAT) scores improve by 92% with AI self-service, compared to laggards with less than 50% improvement.
  • 84% of AI leaders used AI to reduce hold times, while AI laggards saw no reduction.

With an advanced contact center solution, you can even leverage AI to identify the most common reasons people contact your support center. This empowers you to gather insights and optimize these self-service resources to meet customer needs and shorter resolution times.

7. Voice analytics

Voice analytics, especially when paired with sentiment analysis, is a powerful contact center feature. It helps decode a customer’s emotional tone during an interaction, allowing teams to better understand how or why it was positive or negative.

This feature does more than simply record customer conversations—it analyzes the tone and nuances of their speech, identifying emotions such as frustration, satisfaction, or confusion in real time. This capability is incredibly valuable as it allows agents to respond with greater empathy and tailor their interactions to the customer’s emotional state. For instance, if the sentiment analysis picks up on frustration, agents can focus on calming strategies, whereas positive sentiment may suggest a quicker, more seamless interaction..

This insight not only improves the quality of each conversation but also provides actionable data for training and quality assurance. Managers can use this data to identify areas where agents may need support, uncover patterns in customer pain points, and spot trends that help refine customer experience strategies.

8. AI-powered agent assistance 

Agent assistance is one of the most transformative contact center capabilities available today, delivering real-time guidance and relevant information directly to contact center agents during customer interactions. Using AI, it can instantly pull knowledge base articles to help agents intelligently address issues with speed and confidence.

That way, agents don’t have to spend time digging for resources or finding answers. Why? Because they’re already at their fingertips. Plus, agents can dedicate more time to actively listening to and engaging with the customer.
Of course, generative AI takes agent assistance several steps further. For example, Webex Contact Center leverages generative AI to power two unique capabilities:

  • Suggested responses: This Webex Contact Center feature generates replies based on the context of the conversation. With relevant, tailored suggestions, agents can reduce response times and improve the consistency of their answers. This support not only minimizes the cognitive load on agents but also enhances the customer experience by ensuring replies are both precise and personalized.
  • Conversation summaries: Automatic conversation summaries capture and consolidate key details from each chat or call, allowing agents to quickly review the interaction history without requiring customers to repeat themselves. Whether it’s a chat with a virtual agent, a call that got disconnected, or a conversation involving multiple agents, these summaries provide a clear, concise recap of each customer’s journey. This feature is especially valuable when customers transition between virtual and human agents, as it preserves context and ensures continuity.

9. Unified communication and collaboration tools

Integrated collaboration tools are essential for a modern contact center, as they seamlessly connect agents with knowledge workers and other departments, creating a more agile and responsive support environment. When a contact center solution integrates with widely used collaboration platforms—whether that be Webex Calling or Microsoft Teams—agents can easily reach out for information, seek assistance, or coordinate with teams in real time, all within the same interface.

This integration minimizes time lost to switching between platforms and reduces the delays that often arise when agents need input from other departments to resolve complex inquiries. With instant access to subject-matter experts, agents can deliver faster, more accurate responses, enhancing both the speed and quality of customer support.

10. Real-time and historical reporting

Data-driven insights are vital for contact center managers aiming to optimize daily operations and long-term performance. With access to historical and real-time metrics, such as call volume, average handle time, and customer wait times, managers can quickly identify patterns and address operational challenges as they arise.

Real-time insights allow managers to make immediate adjustments, such as reallocating resources during unexpected call spikes or offering additional support to agents handling high call volumes. This responsiveness ensures that service quality remains consistent and that customers experience minimal wait times, even during peak periods.

Historical reports, on the other hand, provide a comprehensive view of performance trends over time. By analyzing these insights, managers can identify recurring issues, such as increased call volumes during certain seasons, or track the impact of workflow changes. This data empowers managers to make informed, strategic decisions, like refining training programs, optimizing staffing schedules, and improving response protocols, all of which can enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and improve the overall customer experience.

11. Open architecture

Did you know that 75% of businesses have as many as 10 disparate customer data systems? It’s true—and worse yet, siloed data can significantly hinder contact center performance. Organizations with disparate customer data systems have 48% longer resolution times and 50% lower CSAT scores than others with connected platforms.

That’s exactly why your contact center software must be highly compatible with the rest of your technology stack, especially customer relationship management (CRM) systems. CRM integration ensures data flows seamlessly between business applications, providing agents with updated customer information. Also, it reduces context switching, ensuring teams can access data from one dashboard.

Ideally, your solution should offer a suite of developer resources, like application programming interfaces (APIs), software development kits, documentation, and support services. Open APIs and other tools make it easy for developers to integrate, customize, and enhance platform functionality. Critically, they also enable teams to innovate AI-powered solutions tailored to their business needs.

12. Centralized management

With a “single pane of glass” dashboard, contact center teams can manage, monitor, and troubleshoot systems in real time. By having all essential functions accessible from one place, they can quickly identify and resolve issues, ensuring minimal downtime and maintaining smooth operations.

A centralized solution with easy administration also provides end-to-end control over security, compliance, and user access, which is crucial for safeguarding sensitive customer data and meeting regulatory standards. Also, customizable, widget-based desktops allow agents to tailor their workspace to fit their unique workflows and preferences. This flexibility not only enhances productivity but also improves agent satisfaction by providing a setup that aligns with individual needs.

Take Control Hub, for example. It’s a comprehensive dashboard where administrators can manage their entire Webex ecosystem, including Webex Contact Center. From here, they can monitor performance, add or delete users, generate reports, and much more.

13. Customer experience management

Knowing how your customers feel isn’t easy, but with the right platform, you can strategically gather information throughout their journey. Post-interaction surveys and customized feedback forms provide direct insights into customer satisfaction and service quality.

By collecting feedback immediately after a customer interaction, whether via text or email, organizations can capture real-time responses while the experience is still fresh. For a more tailored approach, they can use custom surveys designed to match specific interactions, products, or customer segments, making the feedback more relevant and actionable.

In either case, managing surveys within the flow of customer interactions allows contact centers to place them strategically—after resolving complex issues, for example—where responses provide the most meaningful insights. This data-driven focus on improvement ultimately leads to higher customer satisfaction and more agile, responsive support.

14. Agent burnout detection

One of AI’s most important use cases involves agent wellbeing. Stress and burnout are common in the workplace, especially for contact center agents. In fact, agent turnover is twice that of any other profession, with burnout causing 50% of the churn.

Fortunately, AI-driven burnout detection can help prevent turnover—and more importantly, support agent wellness. With Webex Contact Center, you can automatically identify early signs of stress, exhaustion, or burnout. It leverages AI to analyze factors like vocal tone in real time, detecting subtle cues that indicate an agent may be experiencing strain.

This notifies supervisors, who can take timely action to intervene. Whether it be offering a break, providing additional support, or reassigning tasks to lighten the agent’s load, this proactive approach can make a big difference inside and outside the workplace.

15. CSAT score generation

CSAT surveys are an essential tool for gauging customer satisfaction, providing direct feedback on individual interactions, and allowing contact centers to measure how well they’re meeting customer needs. However, these surveys don’t always capture the full picture. Not all customers participate, and even those who do may offer limited responses that don’t fully reflect their experience. This makes it difficult to identify potential issues that weren’t explicitly mentioned.

To bridge this gap, contact centers can use AI-powered CSAT score generation to automatically analyze customer sentiment and conversation transcripts. By examining tone, word choice, and emotional cues throughout the interaction, sentiment analysis detects levels of satisfaction or frustration that surveys might miss. When combined with conversation transcripts, this sentiment data reveals patterns and insights that may go unreported in survey responses alone.

Unlock innovation with Webex Contact Center

Your choice of platform can significantly determine how your contact center performs—and by extension, the quality of your customer experience. The good news? You can find all the contact center capabilities you need in one comprehensive, cloud-based, and AI-powered solution: Webex Contact Center. 

At Cisco, we’re constantly rolling out new features to take our platform to the next level. From AI assistance to burnout detection and everything in between, these capabilities empower you to transform customer experience into a tangible business advantage.

Ready to get started? Learn more about Webex Contact Center today.

These insights lead to actionable strategies that address specific outcomes, expanding the focus beyond classic operational metrics.

The Subtle, Yet Significant Impact

item.title: The journey to agentic AI: redefining what’s possible for ...
item.content:encoded:
For more than a decade, the rhythm of how we work together has been the same: call, message, meet. This paradigm, a product of the convergence of workloads over IP, worked well for us—but also plateaued. We’ve had years of adding choices, channels, and devices, yet the underlying experience has been the same. The question we need to ask is not how to add more, but how to collaborate in a way that’s fundamentally better.

This is where AI changes the game. No longer just an enhancement, AI has become the catalyst for the next generation of collaboration—one that’s more intuitive, intelligent, and impactful. At Webex, we’ve led every wave of AI innovation, from bringing audio, video, and language intelligence together to create Distance Zero experiences that feel like everyone is in the room together, to harnessing generative AI with the Cisco AI Assistant that combines responsible AI with platform-wide productivity capabilities.

What’s next? Agentic AI is the next evolution of AI innovation. A world where AI can predict problems before they happen. Whether that’s troubleshooting issues in a conference room before an important meeting or imagine a utility company that detects a localized power outage before it escalates. AI proactively sends notifications to affected customers, guiding them on safety measures and estimated restoration times—preventing a surge of emergency calls and ensuring a smooth, informed response. A world where AI can elevate an employee from doing hours of tedious task execution to focusing on strategic problems with intelligent insights and creative tools. And a world where IT and leadership have full oversight and guardrails to make the AI experience feel trusted, secure, and seamless.

The ROI of Experience

AI innovation is only useful when it delivers better experiences for employees, customers, and IT. Our guiding principle is that Experience Matters, leveraging AI to improve interactions, collaboration, and overall productivity. Our recent enhancements work together to deliver meaningful value inside customers’ organizations.

Webex asked over 1,000 customers and users across 8 industries and 12 countries to share the impact AI is having on their business. They shared that AI had a significant impact with:

  • 8% reduction in average handle time with AI Assistant for Webex Contact Center
  • 3x faster device deployment compared to other solutions
  • 5+ hours saved per week on tasks like notetaking, finding critical information, and creating content with AI Assistant for Webex Suite

Read the full results of the survey.

Let’s explore from a customer experience and an employee experience perspective how these AI value drivers are reshaping the next era of work to be more scalable, more productive, and ultimately deliver better experiences for everyone.

Creating a Customer Experience Center

Traditional contact centers, primarily reactive in addressing customer inquiries, are evolving into experience centers where every interaction is an opportunity to provide exceptional service. This has been the promise for a long time, but advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence and automation have finally started to make this a reality. Webex is making this possible with the Webex Customer Experience portfolio with tools like AI Agent and AI Assistant that seamlessly integrate with back-office system for automated intent fulfillment, and the Webex Contact Center integration with Epic Systems empowers agents and care-providers with an AI-driven communication platform integrated directly into Epic.

AI Agent is powering more human-like interactions across voice and digital channels

Orderable as of March 31, 2025, the Webex AI Agent revolutionizes self-service by providing personalized, conversational experiences across multiple channels. It facilitates human-like interactions, understanding individual needs and adapting to preferences in real-time. Businesses can easily design and deploy AI Agents tailored to their requirements, choosing between autonomous agents for dynamic conversations or scripted agents with pre-configured responses. With robust integrations into back-office systems, the AI Agent ensures complete resolution of customer issues, enhancing efficiency and customer satisfaction. This innovative approach transforms customer service by making it more intuitive, responsive, and effective.

AI Assistant for Webex Contact Center with Real-time Transcription and Suggested Responses

The Cisco AI Assistant for Webex Contact Center equips agents with automated guidance and context to optimize customer interactions, including generally available Virtual Agent Summaries, Dropped Call Summaries, Automatic CSAT, Topic Analytics, and Agent Wellbeing.

Launching in second quarter 2025, real-time transcription offers instant, accurate, and continuous transcription of conversations during live calls. It ensures agents can clearly follow and understand customer intentions, helping them overcome challenges related to hearing issues, accent comprehension, fast speech, or complex discussions. Suggested responses display contextual real-time recommendations on how the agent should respond or what actions they can take next when working on an interaction. These recommendations are displayed directly within the agent desktop within the AI assistant, equipping agents with the necessary information to reduce call times and enhance customer satisfaction.

Native Epic integration for Webex Contact Center

This new cutting-edge integration equips contact center agents and care providers with Webex’s multi-channel communication platform within Epic Systems (Cheers/Hyperdrive). Using a single user interface, native within Epic, agents will have all essential patient, provider, caregiver, and member medical information and the ability to effortlessly manage interactions at their fingertips, providing streamlined, hyper-personalized, and empathetic support to every interaction.

AI-Powered Employee Experiences for End Users and IT

Delivering exceptional Employee Experiences starts with designing smart workspaces and fostering intelligent interactions that enhance engagement. Our approach focuses on two key groups; end users, who rely on our technology every day to collaborate seamlessly and IT professionals, who ensure these experiences run effortlessly. By empowering both, we create workplaces that are more connected, intuitive and future-proofed.

For end users, Cisco Devices, combined with the Webex Suite, offers a unique value of hardware and software that work seamlessly together, powered by a single platform and unified AI assistant. We’re uplevelling the experience for frontline employees, providing AI tools to make handling customer inquiries seamless across retail locations, help desks, mobile workers, and more. We’re making end users lives’ easier by extending this ecosystem with Workflow Automation with AI Assistant, AI Enterprise Search and Apple AirPlay on Cisco Devices for Microsoft Teams Rooms. Plus, more AI enhancements are upcoming second quarter 2025 availability for Webex Suite including Speaker Identification, AI-generated Vidcast, and Share to 3rd Party Apps for Webex Suite.

On the IT side of the equation, our Full Stack Collaboration approach simplifies deploying and managing these advanced capabilities. By integrating networking, security, and collaboration tools, we provide a cohesive platform that empowers organizations to seamlessly implement AI-driven innovations. With new AI capabilities in Control Hub, admins can tailor Webex AI to their organization and understand detailed AI usage. We’ve further enhanced intelligent workplace management with the beta of Smart Diagnostics that enables AI-powered troubleshooting and device updates across the organization.

Webex Calling Customer Assist

With Webex Calling Customer Assist, AI empowers and extends far beyond the limits of traditional contact centers, arming every employee to deliver seamless, one-to-one support directly from the Webex app. Frontline workers, such as nurses, retail workers, warehouse staff, and knowledge workers, such as local branches and internals help desks, can now effortlessly answer questions and schedule appointments, providing a local and specialized level of care.

Workflow Automation with AI Assistant

Instead of jotting down a list of To Do Items, you can now just act directly inside the Webex AI Assistant. Ask it to create a lead, update a record, or even attach a meeting summary with popular apps Salesforce, Jira, and ServiceNow, with more apps coming soon.

AI Enterprise Search

Knowledge workers spend a significant amount of time each week looking for information and documents across a number of apps. With connectors across many enterprise apps such as Outlook, Salesforce, and ServiceNow-made possible with Glean-users can enhance discussions, search Webex, and speed up decision-making with knowledge graphs and connectors.

Apple AirPlay on Cisco Devices for Microsoft Teams Rooms

AirPlay on Cisco Devices is now available for Microsoft Teams Rooms, enabling instant wireless content sharing from an iPhone, iPad or Mac to Cisco Devices.

AI Capabilities in Control Hub

Webex Control Hub is a centralized place for managing AI across Webex Suite and Devices, with coming soon enhancements for managing the company’s AI ecosystem across language models, customizing AI features, and enabling workflow integrations with complete control over security and privacy. Just like Webex AI early adopters who are seeing amazing results, Webex Admins will soon be able to measure their own AI adoption and metrics inside their organization.

Intelligent Workplace Management with Smart Diagnostics

Put agentic AI to work for your IT team with Smart Diagnostics, now in Beta. Smart Diagnostics works in tandem with AI-powered Workspace Ranking to intelligently identify which workspaces need IT attention, based on factors such as occupancy and criticality. Leveraging AI, Smart Diagnostics will deliver any context relevant to the issue at hand in an easy to digest and actionable format to resolve the problem. Smart Diagnostics goes one step further and provides the option to implement its suggested fixes, even providing a bulk action option to conduct an update across all your devices.

There’s more to see live at Enterprise Connect 25

We’re so excited about what this next wave of AI innovation can bring to your organization—from transforming contact centers into experience centers to empowering employees with AI Agents and Workflows that ultimately make them more efficient and more engaged. Join me, Snorre Kjesbu, live on stage at Enterprise Connect for the Cisco Keynote: Experiences Amplified–How AI Can Fuel Better Employee and Customer Experiences. We’ll show you the latest AI innovations developed to supercharge collaboration, customer experience, and workplace productivity. And be sure to tune in to our additional seven sessions, private booth tours, 1:1 meetings, and, of course, our signature Webex Café experience. So much to explore and we can’t wait to share it with you.

item.title: 6 New Ways to Transform Workspace Reservation
item.content:encoded:
We’ve all been there in one way or another—the struggle to find an available space, double-booked rooms, workspaces occupied by ‘ghost’ meetings, and clunky room calendars. Fortunately, smart workplace technology comes to the rescue to make these workplace frustrations a thing of the past. The combined deployment of Cisco Room Navigator touch panels, the Cisco Scheduler app, and Cisco Spaces provides a compound workplace experience fabric to help your users remove these frictions and make the office worth the commute.

In this article, we’ve brought you six innovations from Cisco to help you streamline the room booking and hot desking experience while making the workplace journey more efficient.

1. Deploy Cisco Room Navigator in stylish carbon black

Today organizations are looking at technology that seamlessly supports their workplace interior design choices. At Cisco, we design collaboration devices that not only promote sustainability through circular design and low energy modes but also provide flexibility with color options. 

We are thrilled to share that the Cisco Room Navigator touch panel will be available in a new stylish, carbon black finish starting from May 2025. The new color option is perfect to bring sleek elegance to any modern workspace decor and complements the existing first light variant of the touch device. By doing so, it allows you to equip spaces with meeting room touch controllers and scheduling displays, either mounted on the wall or used as a tabletop device, that best suit your workplace environment.

2. Automatically release unused spaces  

With the most recent updates to the native Cisco Scheduler application, you can allow users to check into or out of a meeting room they previously booked with a single tap on the Room Navigator. Beyond a new, intuitive visual experience and custom branding options, the app features a native automation to increase booking efficiency by preventing wasted real estate caused by ‘ghost’ meetings.  

Rooms booked but left empty are no longer a problem. You no longer need third-party sensors or cumbersome configuration to solve that, as the solution natively uses sensor data from the Cisco video device deployed to detect if the room is unoccupied within a predefined time window and automatically release it so it’s free to be used by your team – thus optimizing space usage and booking efficiency.

3. Pre-book a hot desk with Cisco Spaces 

For a seamless workplace journey, employees expect to control their experience at every step of the way. Coming soon, users will be able to find and pre-book a hot desking space using Cisco Spaces–either through the Cisco Spaces mobile app or the Cisco Spaces 3D interactive map once they arrive at the office. With Cisco Spaces, finding your desk is a breeze and allows the user to confirm the booking on the Cisco desk video collaboration device or the Cisco desk phone, such as the new Cisco Desk Phone 9800 Series.

The combination of Cisco devices and Cisco Spaces removes the stress of employees wondering if hot desks are available in the area they want to sit and provides a personalized space and collaboration capabilities in one device. IT doesn’t need to buy and piece together multiple devices to do this.

4. Book a meeting room in advance

Cisco Scheduler can also remove friction through advanced booking functionality throughout the day. Your employees may want to book a room on the go but there are occasions where the need is to reserve the space ahead of time. Available now, Cisco Scheduler allows you to book a meeting room ahead by displaying available slots and providing the option to schedule meetings in advance for designated time intervals.

5. Check into an ad-hoc space 

But not all your meeting rooms may be bookable spaces. Focus rooms and quiet rooms are mostly ad-hoc, shared workspaces for focused work or spontaneous collaboration that your team can use without ahead booking required for more convenience and a more efficient use of the environment. Using the Cisco Room Navigator, you can now run the Cisco Scheduler for ad-hoc rooms, even spaces with a device configured for hot desking, without Webex calendar setup required–allowing your team to reserve these spaces for impromptu collaboration.

6. Run the Microsoft Teams panel experience 

In case you have standardized on other workplace apps, Room Navigator has been offering an open approach to integration to support your go-to workplace apps. In addition to the Microsoft Teams Rooms Console app for meeting controls, late last year the Room Navigator obtained certification for the native Microsoft Teams panel experience as well to support your Microsoft Teams rooms with seamless reservation functionality. 

Alternatively, you can seamlessly run the Cisco Scheduler app paired with an MTR-enabled workspace to enjoy a combination of advanced Cisco room booking outside of the space while bringing elevated Microsoft Teams conferencing in the room.

These innovations are more than just tech upgrades already enjoyed by thousands of organizations across the globe —they’re about creating a future-proofed workplace. Allowing your teams to see room availability from a distance, reserve the meeting room on the go or in advance, or pre-book a hot desk for the day, alongside automatically releasing unused spaces can help your users make the most of their time and stay productive while they’re in the office.

item.title: Iberdrola Achieves 20% Reduction in Video Conferencing Costs with ...
item.content:encoded:
Iberdrola is a Spanish energy global leader in renewable energies that has existed for over 180 years and focuses its efforts on providing renewable power to populations in numerous countries, spanning Europe as well as North and South America, Australia, Asia. The company employs over 40,000 people, with a push underway to hire 10,000 more. and employs more than 400,000 people indirectly

An organization this large and ambitious needs a reliable communication network to connect its many teams around the world. In the past, this meant using on-premises technology platforms paired with Cisco devices. Following a recent migration, however, Iberdrola has entered the cloud via Webex Meetings.

A massive global network transitioning to the cloud

Two and a half years ago, the Iberdrola team decided to migrate its global communication network to the cloud. This was a big decision, due to the 800 existing meeting rooms, each of which would need high-quality communications technology to go with its installed hardware.

Rather than automatically selecting Webex systems to go along with the Cisco devices it already used, the company studied the whole market. In the end, however, Webex won out. Iberdrola saw the value of having a real partnership with both Cisco and Webex, one that could maintain the consistency of devices and platforms across the company’s global network.

“It is very important for us that when there is an incident, we can resolve it knowing that it is the same device, whether in Avangrid, the United States, Neoenergía, Brazil, or from here, San Agustín del Guadalix Madrid, Spain,” said Manuel Muñoz, Iberdrola’s global head of AV communications and VIP support. “This allows us to more easily assess any possible incidents that may arise. All users have the same experience. That is fundamental.”

The resulting solution has helped the organization stay connected, while also assisting with its efforts to achieve green operations and display corporate responsibility—vital qualities for a business in the clean energy space.

“I am a firm supporter of human contact, it is crucial, but where human contact does not reach, technology has to make up for it and the technology that we offer in meeting rooms right now can make up for the lack of that human contact,” said Muñoz.  “They also make us more resilient with the environment, we reduce travel, we reduce the carbon footprint and that is very important for a company like Iberdrola.”

A need for quality and simplicity

The stability and reliability of communications are seen as absolute musts for Iberdrola, across both everyday users and especially the VIP tier of users. VIP, according to Muñoz, means “Those users whose communications should at no point be seen damaged or reduced in quality.”

Alongside the need for stable, high-quality connections exists an equal need for a simple user experience. During the beginning of his tenure with Iberdrola, Muñoz was disappointed by the many cables in the meeting rooms, as well as the fact that employees were sometimes unsure of how they would connect to the video conferencing system. This could drastically slow down meetings and increase employee stress.

Using cutting-edge Cisco Devices such as the Room Bar, Room Bar Pro and Desk Pro, connected by the Webex platform, the Iberdrola system has managed to remove 12 kilometers of cables. Each room now has a self-explanatory interface with a single point to hook up devices. To underline the simplicity of the new system, all meeting room screens now display connection instructions, with no need for extra documentation.

“If in doubt, just look at the screen and follow four simple steps to connect, wired or wireless,” said Muñoz. “We don’t need paper, we don’t need anything. It is already in all the rooms in the world.”

Microsoft Teams is the key communications platform for numerous Iberdrola employees. This means the ease of integration between Teams, Cisco Devices, and Webex systems is a major benefit. Rather than being forced to only communicate through the Webex platform, users can set up Teams on their devices seamlessly,

The streamlined new system allows the company to offer a three-tiered support system:

  • Level one is a two-person team using Webex Control Hub to handle first incidents affecting any of the 800 conference rooms.
  • Level two is a group that remotely monitors issues and offers corrections.
  • Level three is the engineering team assigned to deal with deeper matters in detail.

The Webex environment provides the observational capacity for these small groups to look after all the company’s technology needs.

Advanced features serve as pieces of the whole

When it comes to artificial intelligence (AI), Iberdrola is taking a measured approach to which features it implements, driven by security and compliance requirements. The team has already been working AI features into its various communications platforms, always viewing the technology as a component, rather than a reason unto itself.

“The implementation of artificial intelligence solutions will improve productivity as they are already doing, because we have not been applying artificial intelligence for six months. We have been applying it for much longer,” offered Muñoz. “The end is the solution that is offered to the user. That’s what’s important. Artificial intelligence is one part. It’s a wrench, it’s a bolt, it’s not the whole thing.”

Muñoz adds that AI has a variety of uses that might not be obvious at first. For example, RoomOS uses advanced AI to intelligently adjust cameras and keep speakers in view as they move, creating a more dynamic and engaging meeting experience.

Beyond AI, Iberdrola is taking advantage of the new Webex platform to run regulated simultaneous translation services for its global conferences. Bringing in translators as needed via video call reduces the need for travel, cutting the company’s carbon footprint and increasing the resilience of its communications network.

Tangible benefits and an ongoing partnership

The new deployment has been a success, both in terms of usage level and the amount of utility and satisfaction users have gotten from it. The baseline metrics are impressive: Comparing previous and current spending reveals that the costs of running video conferences have fallen by 20%. The company has also reduced its energy use and pollutant output.

Iberdrola’s internal research initially indicated there would be less need for video conferencing following the end of COVID-19 work-from-home mandates, but the number of calls has risen by 9%. The team sees this as a vote of confidence in the new communications system, indicating that users feel comfortable and secure conferencing through their devices and installed technology in meeting rooms.

The tech support team has observed the impacts of the system due to a change in the tone of the tickets they receive. While before the transition to Webex cloud systems, most of the support requests came from users asking for help, the team now receives frequent messages of thanks and praise.

“Anyone can open a ticket and say ‘I don’t like the solution, I disagree,'” explained Muñoz. “Currently we receive more positive messages than negative ones. And this is a trend change. They tell us thank you for making our lives easier. This is the success we have achieved.”

The partnership Iberdrola’s team envisioned during the search for a new partner has been realized through its Webex and Cisco deployments.

Contact us to see how your organization can connect its operations, domestically or around the world.

item.content:encoded:
We came together at WebexOne 2024 in Fort Lauderdale to celebrate the achievements of 62 exceptional Webex Customer Award finalists and 18 winners, recognized for their unparallelled contributions to innovation. We’d like to take a moment to celebrate the achievements of five winners who are using Cisco devices and the Webex Suite to reimagine the employee experience and create smarter workspaces at their organizations. These innovators – Advanced Micro Devices, University of Wollongong, USI Insurance, Akamai, and the Dallas Cowboys are making waves across diverse sectors, from computer technology and higher education to professional football and insurance, each of these customers stand out as innovators and champions for their forward-thinking ideas, embrace of AI, and innovative approaches to overcoming collaboration challenges in this new era of hybrid work. Let’s explore their remarkable stories and celebrate their success.

1. AMD boosts efficiency with 80% utilization of collaboration tools and 98% conference room occupancy using Cisco Devices

In 2023, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), a renowned global semiconductor powerhouse based in Santa Clara, California, embarked on an impressive journey to revolutionize workplace collaboration. With a vast workforce of over 35,000 employees spread across six continents, AMD took a bold step forward by upgrading their conference rooms with cutting-edge Cisco Devices. This strategic move replaced their outdated systems, which had been in use for an average of eight years and marked a significant leap in enhancing connectivity and collaboration across their global operations. With a renewed emphasis on office work and global collaboration, the integration of one-touch join and quad cam functionality into their conference rooms has notably improved meeting quality and user engagement.

A standout success of this initiative is the Technostar site in Bangalore, AMD’s largest global Cisco deployment and the first to fully adopt the new standard. These enhancements have delivered remarkable outcomes: some of AMD’s 1,396 global conference rooms now boast a 98% occupancy rate, operate 12 hours a day, and achieve over 80% utilization of collaboration tools. The transition to Cisco technology has also halved the number of problematic rooms and helpdesk tickets, earning enthusiastic feedback from users and executives alike.

2. University of Wollongong’s global education revolution with Cisco Devices

The University of Wollongong (UOW) is renowned for academic excellence, serving over 33,000 students across 13 campuses worldwide. With nine campuses in Australia and additional sites in Dubai, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and India, UOW ranks among the top 1% of universities globally, underscoring its commitment to providing comprehensive education tailored to a diverse student body.

At the heart of this mission is UOW’s embrace of cutting-edge technology, particularly through the implementation of Cisco Devices. By standardizing on Cisco’s robust video solutions, UOW has transformed thousands of learning environments—from expansive lecture halls to intimate huddle rooms—into seamless collaboration and communication hubs across all campuses.

Setting new standards at the university

Prior to 2017, UOW managed a costly and complex multi-vendor system. Transitioning to Cisco’s unified platform marked a pivotal shift, enabling the creation of modern, AI-enabled, cloud-managed rooms that support a broad spectrum of educational activities. Whether it’s the sophisticated “campfire” council room, equipped with 13 screens and five cameras, or versatile mobile classrooms, Cisco’s technology optimizes each space for dynamic learning and interaction.

The integration of the Webex Suite further enriches UOW’s educational experience, offering features such as real-time language translation, multi-content sharing, and digital whiteboarding. These tools enhance accessibility and engagement for both in-room and remote participants, ensuring a fully inclusive learning environment.

UOW’s strategic partnership with Cisco not only strengthens its infrastructure but also reinforces its position as a leader in innovative, technology-driven education. Through this collaboration, UOW continues to set the benchmark for how educational institutions can leverage technology to improve learning outcomes and foster global connectivity.

3. USI’s AI transformation: elevating collaboration in the hybrid work era

As a leader in insurance brokerage and consulting, USI is pioneering the transformation of team collaboration through the power of artificial intelligence. Since its founding in 1994, USI has seen remarkable growth, generating nearly $3 billion in revenue and employing over 10,000 associates across 200 offices nationwide.

In April 2024, USI Insurance took a significant step forward by joining the early access program for Cisco AI Assistant and transitioning to the new Webex Suite architecture. This strategic move has dramatically transformed meetings at USI, making them more productive and inclusive. The Cisco AI Assistant has notably improved call quality, allowing seamless meetings even with unstable internet conditions. With features that capture sidebar conversations, remote participants are now fully included, resulting in a 260% increase in Cisco AI Assistant usage and a substantial boost in meeting activity.

Harnessing Cisco’s AI innovations to redefine hybrid work and communication

Cisco’s cinematic meetings and Crossview technology have further elevated the hybrid work experience, ensuring that all in-person or remote participants enjoy inclusive and effective meetings. Among AI-driven advancements, automatic meeting transcriptions and summarizations are standout features for USI. These tools have revolutionized meetings by allowing participants to focus on discussions without the distraction of notetaking. Attendees can easily catch up on missed meetings with AI-generated transcriptions and action items, leading to increased participation and engagement.

USI has also adopted Vidcast, Webex’s asynchronous video capability, to enhance communication, minimizing the need for live meetings. The marketing team can craft personalized video messages for clients, saving time and boosting outreach. Vidcast’s AI features, such as automatic summarization and chapter creation, have proven invaluable, leading to the replacement of previous solutions. Furthermore, the Webex AI Codec has resolved challenges with home internet quality, improving call experiences and showcasing the potential of Cisco AI Assistant to address real-world issues.

These innovations showcase how USI is harnessing AI to enhance collaboration, streamline communication, and adapt to the evolving landscape of hybrid work, setting a new standard for efficiency and engagement in the industry.

4. Akamai achieves 90% employee engagement rate with Cisco devices & Webex collaboration solutions

Akamai, renowned for its expertise in cloud computing, security, and content delivery services, is more than just a tech giant with over 10,900 employees. The company is a pioneer in leveraging Cisco’s advanced collaboration tools to drive innovation and efficiency across its operations.

By fully embracing the Webex Suite, along with Slido for polling, Vidcast for asynchronous video messaging, and Cisco devices, Akamai has seamlessly integrated these technologies into its daily workflows. Their proactive approach is evident in their active participation in beta testing, where they provide crucial feedback to refine and enhance these tools.

Akamai’s dedication to cutting-edge technology is further demonstrated by their use of  Webex Control Hub. This powerful platform enables them to manage their technology portfolio with precision and access comprehensive analytics, ensuring they remain ahead of the curve.

The results are clear—Akamai has achieved an impressive 90% employee engagement rate with these collaboration tools. This not only highlights the successful integration of these technologies but also underscores their positive impact on the company’s operations and employee satisfaction.

In a world where effective collaboration is key to success, Akamai’s strategic use of Cisco’s collaboration tools sets a benchmark for innovation and operational excellence.

5. Innovating with Cisco Devices: The Dallas Cowboys’ Winning Strategy

The Dallas Cowboys, known for their legendary history and Super Bowl victories, are taking their game off the field by embracing Cisco’s cutting-edge collaboration technology. This innovative drive is showcased through their use of Cisco devices at key locations like their high-tech headquarters, The Star, and the iconic AT&T Stadium.

With Cisco Phones, Room Kits, and Desk Minis in their playbook, the Cowboys have transformed how they communicate and collaborate. These devices ensure smooth interactions, whether in their expansive offices or during remote team huddles. For team owner Jerry Jones and the coaching staff, Cisco’s dependable audio and video solutions keep them in sync no matter where they are.

At the core of this technological transformation is Cisco’s Control Hub, a robust platform that enables the Cowboys to monitor and adjust their extensive network of devices. This allows them to address any issues before they interfere with the game plan, ensuring that communications remain seamless.

By harnessing Cisco’s robust solutions, the Dallas Cowboys illustrate how cutting-edge technology can elevate both fan experiences and team operations. As America’s Team continues to set the pace in hybrid work and collaboration, they’re redefining excellence in the sports world and beyond.

Read their full case study here.

Empowering industry leaders to innovate and transform

Reflecting on these remarkable stories of innovation, it’s evident that Webex’s collaboration technology serves as a catalyst for transformation across diverse industries.

From AMD’s enhanced conference rooms to the University of Wollongong’s global education revolution, USI’s AI-driven collaboration advancements, Akamai’s exemplary employee engagement, and the Dallas Cowboys’ winning strategy, each organization has harnessed Cisco’s solutions to redefine their operations and set new benchmarks in their fields.

These award-winning organizations showcase the power of embracing technology to drive innovation and efficiency, paving the way for a future where seamless communication and collaboration lead to success. As we celebrate these achievements, we eagerly anticipate how these and other forward-thinking organizations will continue to evolve and inspire within the ever-changing landscape of employee engagement and connectivity.

item.title: What is omnichannel customer experience? The complete guide for 2025.
item.content:encoded:
The concept of an omnichannel experience is transforming businesses globally. But what exactly does omnichannel customer experience mean for your contact center? Omnichannel customer service is reshaping how companies engage with consumers. Implementing an effective omnichannel strategy requires the right contact center platform to ensure seamless interactions.

This guide explores what omnichannel customer experience is, how omnichannel customer service works, and how businesses can leverage it to enhance customer satisfaction and operational efficiency.

What is omnichannel customer service?

Omnichannel customer service is a strategy that enables businesses to provide seamless customer support across multiple communication channels, including phone calls, SMS, email, social media, live chat, and chatbots. Unlike traditional models, an omnichannel approach ensures that customer interactions remain connected, allowing for a smooth and uninterrupted experience.

What is omnichannel customer experience?

Omnichannel customer experience is the broader strategy that encompasses omnichannel customer service. The goal is to provide a consistent and personalized journey across all touchpoints, ensuring that customers can transition between channels without losing context or repeating information. A key component of an omnichannel strategy is ensuring that all channels are interconnected and provide a seamless customer journey.

Omnichannel vs. multichannel: key differences.

While both omnichannel and multichannel strategies involve multiple communication channels, the main difference lies in integration. A multichannel approach allows customer interactions across different platforms, but these channels operate independently. In contrast, an omnichannel strategy ensures that all channels are interconnected, providing a unified customer experience.

For example, in a multichannel environment, a customer may start an inquiry via social media but must start over when calling a support line. With an omnichannel approach, the customer’s history is accessible across all platforms, enabling a seamless and efficient experience.

Why omnichannel customer service is essential.

Customer service is a form of marketing. It makes people happier with a company and, therefore, likelier to stay subscribed or to re-buy. It also means customers are more likely to recommend a business to others. Because an omnichannel contact center can be critical to customer service, that makes it a form of omnichannel marketing.

Executing an omnichannel customer engagement strategy successfully requires consistency. This can be difficult because customer expectations are forever changing and people are increasingly expecting a deeply personalized customer experience. That can be challenging to deliver, but omnichannel support can definitely help. The key is to avoid a disjointed customer journey, as this can adversely affect customer retention and loyalty.

What are the key benefits of omnichannel customer support? Some of the primary advantages of an omnichannel strategy include:

Faster time to resolution.

Let’s say an organization operates an inbound call center and offers no other form of contact for customer engagement. Not only will this put off many customers and potential customers from contacting the organization, it also creates a kind of bottleneck. A company can hire as many agents as it wants, but those agents can still only interact with customers via phone calls. This can mean long wait times for customers and it can be exhausting for call center agents.

An omnichannel approach—powered by a contact solution that allows for easy movement across different channels—speeds up query resolution. Many customer issues and questions are relatively simple. An email, a social media interaction, or a chatbot—AI or otherwise—can often solve these issues. This avoids a customer having to call a contact center and wait on hold for half an hour just to talk to an agent for two minutes. The increased efficiency of an omnichannel strategy can reduce the time to resolution significantly.

Improved agent retention.

A company can invest in the best contact center solutions and have the best intentions in mind, but ultimately, a contact center is only as good as its agents. Hiring the right quantity and quality of staff is crucial for contact center performance—as is keeping those agents.

Burnout is a big problem in a contact center environment. This can be especially true for call centers. Having to always take or make another call can exhaust agents, causing them to slow down at work or ultimately leave for another job.

Furthermore, it may be difficult to hire the best candidates, because they may prefer to work in a contact center that allows them a variety of ways to interact with customers. An omnichannel contact center can give agents that variety, letting them respond to emails, social media messages, chats, or SMS/text messages on certain days, certain shifts, or sometimes just to break up the monotony of fielding phone call after phone call.

Increased customer engagement.

It’s not in a company’s interest to make it difficult for customers to interact with them. Customer engagement is crucial to just about any organization’s success, so it’s logical to make it as easy as possible for a customer to engage with it. An increase in positive customer interactions can lead to increased customer loyalty; customers feel better about a brand, more valued by that brand, and that the brand cares about them and their business.

None of these benefits can transpire if it’s too difficult for customers to engage with a company or if they get the impression that any engagement must occur on the company’s terms, making them feel uncomfortable and left out. An omnichannel approach makes it easy for customers to interact with an organization, empowering them to do so via any medium they like. It also allows for that engagement to happen quicker and more conveniently.

Increased customer satisfaction.

Higher levels of customer engagement don’t automatically lead to higher levels of customer satisfaction, but there’s a strong connection between the two. Even if a customer encounters a problem with a company’s product or service, if they can access help for that issue quickly and conveniently, they’re still likely to be satisfied.

An omnichannel approach acknowledges customer preference. It makes it easy for customers to reach out to an organization with their questions and problems. It also means they are less likely to procrastinate when an issue arises, which is important because a customer’s own procrastination can lead to them feeling more dissatisfied and negative about a company.

For example, if someone feels uncomfortable making a phone call, they might put off some troubleshooting they need. As time goes by and they’re continuously unable to use a product, they may resent the company who made the product, even if that company has an inbound call center with plenty of agents available. However, if that company had a chatbot or text channel available, that same customer could contact the organization and receive the troubleshooting help they need in minutes, and thus feel much more satisfied with their purchase and their relationship with the business.

Greater cost optimization.

It’s usually cheaper for an organization to retain an agent rather than search for a replacement and train them. The same logic applies to customer retention; it’s often better and more cost-effective to keep the customers a company has as opposed to looking for new ones to replace those who have left. Customer retention boosts the lifetime value of that customer. This translates into revenue and it also decreases acquisition costs.

Omnichannel capability can be an important factor in customer loyalty. High levels of customer engagement and customer satisfaction can lead to higher retention rates. By simply shifting some call center agents to operate chatbots, social media response channels, and/or email messaging—and equipping them with an efficient contact center solution—a business can achieve a significant rise in customer retention. It can be just as effective as any customer loyalty program.

Streamlined channel activation.

Brands that have an established omnichannel strategy can design and activate new touchpoints quicker. This can be a big competitive advantage. Meeting customers where they are breaks down barriers. Being able to activate and continue customer interactions on one or more channels that suit the customer helps streamline operations. Otherwise, bottlenecks may occur, and customers will experience long wait times before reaching an agent.

Better data utilization.

Omnichannel support doesn’t work well without customer data synchronization. A customer may contact an organization via phone call one month, by email the next, and then through social media another time. It may be critical for the organization to verify it is the same customer in each case. It may also be crucial for each of the different agents to know why the customer contacted the center previously and if a previous agent helped resolve their query, and how.

This is why it’s necessary to support an omnichannel strategy with data synchronization. A contact center solution that makes it easy for agents to log data and store it is key. This way, when a customer calls back, a different agent can access that customer’s data quickly.

A solution with an easy-to-use dashboard that prominently displays relevant data, or where to access that data, is valuable. This helps to avoid data silos. Some companies track all the data they need, but if they don’t have a simple way to share that data across agents and departments, then they can’t utilize it to their benefit.

How does omnichannel strategy work?

What does an omnichannel approach actually look like in practice? Let’s examine an example of an organization that moved to an omnichannel model and the results it achieved by doing so.

Cover-More

Cover-More is a global travel insurance provider. They were already looking at ways of expanding their use of cloud-based solutions and hybrid or remote work before the COVID-19 pandemic began, but when it did strike, they had to accelerate their plans. Cover-More selected Webex Contact Center and cloud calling to help them achieve their goals and successfully launched them across their entire global customer service network in just one day.

Webex offers an intuitive omnichannel solution with real-time global reporting and data analytics. While Cover-More’s focus may have initially been expanding their cloud solutions and enabling remote work, they found they had unlocked major benefits to their customer support services, too.

“Our customers won’t necessarily want to just call us—they may want to email us—or SMS—they might want to use chat—they might want to use Facebook. Webex gives us that ability to have that discussion on how we’re going to better serve our customers,” explained James Hill, Global Manager, Infrastructure and Cloud.

With Webex, Cover-More was able to migrate almost 300 agents, upgrade its IT stack, streamline workflows, and make travel insurance more accessible by integrating with business partners. “By removing all the old stuff, and moving to Webex, we actually saved over 30 percent on our operating costs year over year,” said Hill.

This goes to show how an omnichannel strategy—with the right contact center solution behind it—can improve efficiency, reduce costs, and make an organization more accessible to its customers and potential customers.

How to implement an omnichannel approach

The benefits of an omnichannel strategy are clear now. But just knowing a strategy can be beneficial doesn’t mean an organization will go out tomorrow and begin implementing an omnichannel approach. Many businesses have to overcome inertia to make significant changes to how their contact centers operate, even if they’re aware of the potential advantages of doing so.

That’s why it’s important to know how to approach an omnichannel marketing strategy. Having a framework for how to transition to an omnichannel strategy can get past organizational inertia. Here are five best practices for building an omnichannel contact center:

Centralize customer data.

As mentioned above, data silos create fragmented journeys. This happens when all the data exists somewhere, but center agents can’t or don’t know how to access it. This can make customer interactions longer and less pleasant. There are few things more aggravating for a customer contacting an organization to address an ongoing or recurring issue, only for the agent on the other end of the channel to ask them a series of questions they’ve already answered.

A comprehensive contact center solution can solve this problem. A good solution makes it easy to track, store, access, and share customer data. In seconds, any agent working any channel can access a customer’s information. This includes basic information, such as their name, account number, and location, but it can include more in-depth information, too. For example, a customer’s account profile in an efficient contact center solution might also list their reasons for contacting the center previously, with a label for the issue they were experiencing and whether the agent responding was able to resolve that issue.

Map the customer journey.

Webex Contact Center helps companies centralize their customer data and map customer journeys. It’s a comprehensive solution that can help on-premise and cloud-based contact centers. With a platform like Webex Contact Center, brands can activate customer data by orchestrating the optimal customer journey map.

With that map, an organization can use tools like the virtual flow builder to enable the next-best action decisions and route inbound engagements to the best possible solution. That solution might be a virtual agent or a human agent, but whatever is the best fit for that customer, Webex Contact Center can help agents find it and assist the customer in the quicker, most efficient ways.

Leverage AI-powered self-service.

Contact center AI is becoming increasingly important, especially for omnichannel strategies.

One way to ease the workload on contact center agents is to introduce an AI-powered chatbot. These can operate as virtual agents, using AI to learn about customer needs and address them. Crucially, these virtual agents must communicate with customers in a way that feels human. Even if the customers know they’re interacting with an AI chatbot, if it responds with stilted or unnatural language, the customers might feel uncomfortable or frustrated.

If the virtual agent can respond in a human-like cadence and provide quick answers and solutions, this can speed up the customer interaction process significantly. Customers can begin to address their concerns without waiting for a live agent. Some customers may not need to interact with a human agent at all. By automating routine interactions, chatbots help manage call volume, allowing agents to focus on more complicated cases while customers with simpler queries can enjoy a quick and convenient path to resolution.

Contact center AI can also help power interactive voice response (IVR). An IVR system can answer a call and guide the caller through an automated menu, helping them reach the appropriate resources quickly. AI can strengthen IVR by providing Natural Language Processing (NLP) and speech recognition.

NLP helps IVR systems understand and process language input from callers. This allows for more natural and conversational IVR interactions; callers can speak as they normally do. They don’t have to over-enunciate and speak abnormally slowly to be understood. Nor do they have to navigate rigid menu options.

An AI-powered speech recognition system enables the transcription and interpretation of spoken language with a high level of accuracy. Callers can interact with the system using voice commands. Advanced speech recognition technology allows IVR systems to understand a broad range of accents and dialects. For many callers, this type of interaction is preferable to pushing a button to respond, especially when using a mobile phone with a touch screen.

Analyze customer experience data.

An omnichannel approach can help organizations analyze the customer experience they provide. Something as simple as an email after an interaction can log useful data about the customer journey and experience. Webex Contact Center can help companies track and compile customer experience data across each communication channel.

One important piece of data is the customer effort score, or CES. This measures the relative effort required for a customer to complete a task or interaction. CES can give organizations a vital insight into how easy or difficult their customer interactions are. Customers don’t want to experience friction when trying to contact a business to resolve an issue, so the easier it is for them to do this, the more satisfied they’re likely to be.

Deliver a personalized experience.

Customers don’t want to feel like just another number. They want to feel valued and recognized. This underscores the importance of delivering a personalized experience. They don’t expect contact center agents to know them personally, but they do want each agent to understand their critical information as it relates to the business.

Webex Contact Center provides agents with real-time visibility into previous customer survey responses. This allows them to personalize interactions. Critically, they can also access information from previous customer queries, regardless of which channel they used. An agent answering a phone call can find all the same customer information as one responding to an email.

Optimize the customer journey with Webex Contact Center.

Omnichannel support can bring so many benefits to an organization’s contact center. From operational advantages such as increased contact center efficiency and agent retention to customer experience benefits such as improved customer satisfaction and customer loyalty, an omnichannel strategy is a great approach for your contact center. It’s great for right now, and because it allows for scalability, it can help your organization grow, too.

To support an omnichannel strategy properly, though, you need the right tools. Learn more about Webex Contact Center and how it enables effective and efficient omnichannel capabilities.
