item.title: Distance Zero: Improving Performance by Tightening Organizational ...
item.content:encoded:
As we exited 2024 and entered 2025, previously established remote and hybrid work models and increasingly common return-to-office strategies all remained in a remarkable state of fluctuation. There are no strong indicators of this changing anytime soon. Each of these employee deployment strategies has its pros and cons. We’ve seen many well-known organizations publicly announce their stance, with untold numbers of lesser-known organizations likewise making their choices. Each must do what’s best for their business, customers, culture, and employees. Discussions with customers and collaboration industry participants at the ISE AV tradeshow in Barcelona last week further validated this position.

In recognition of these dynamics Cisco has, for almost two years, championed the concept of Distance Zero—a vision where technology, thoughtfully applied, can dissolve the boundaries of space and time. The idea is to help teams feel closer, collaborate seamlessly, and celebrate successes together, regardless of where they are.

Distance Zero: Overcome obstacles and turn distance to your advantage with AI-powered Cisco devices.

The Distance Zero perspective extends beyond technology as a tool: it’s about technology’s role as a human enabler. How do organizations transform the rituals of work—meetings, brainstorming sessions, even year-end reflections—into moments that strengthen culture and spark creativity? What does it take to create a sense of “here-ness” when teams are dispersed across cities, countries, or even continents?

The Distance Zero concept is not at all about company leaders choosing workstyles for their workforces. Rather, it’s about empowering employees to be present, included, and productive for their individual, their team’s and the organization’s success. This ubiquitous presence, or “here-ness”, is underpinned by connectedness with others and to information, regardless of location.

These constructs align precisely with the intent of unified communications, which aims to equip users with anywhere, anytime access to a rich suite of integrated communications tools used to effectively collaborate and share information. Over the past decade, rapidly evolving communications technologies have furnished business users with an expanding array of software applications (soft clients, presence management, one-on-one and team chat, SMS, email, voicemail/unified messaging, voice and video calling and conferencing, content sharing, and document collaboration) and user interfaces (desktop and mobile soft clients, business phones, headsets, video conferencing and collaboration endpoints) from which these applications are accessed.

Frost Radar: Meeting Room Devices 2024

Frost & Sullivan ranks Cisco the global leader in conferencing devices due to relentless innovation and AI-powered experiences.

More recently, the concept of Distance Zero has gained even greater relevance to organizations looking to tighten the bonds among their employees. Shifting workforce demographics, evolving workstyles, and the digitization of business make it clear that advanced communications tools are necessary for employees to be meaningfully present and connected. Today’s employees expect employers to provide better or equivalent technology for their jobs compared to what they use in their personal lives. Frost & Sullivan survey data show that IT and telecom decision makers (ITDMs) are addressing elevated employee requirements when purchasing communications and collaboration solutions. Among surveyed organizations, 82% select solutions and providers that offer the best end-user features and functionality, and achieve wide user buy-in. Furthermore, productivity best practices established over time have engrained a wide range of applications and devices into the fabric of modern work, with chat and video conferencing being recent prominent examples.

To realize the vision of Distance Zero, organizations must provide employees the flexibility to choose the tools that best serve the purpose of each moment. The context of relationships also steers when and why certain tools are used. As in their personal lives, employees gravitate toward certain modalities and devices that best address the who, what, where, and when of the information at hand.

  • Voice calling remains mission-critical for most organizations, with its use underscoring the importance of personally delivering information or collaborating in real time.
  • In many environments, voicemail has become a mechanism for both the calling and receiving parties to share information yet avoid having a real-time voice conversation.
  • An often-expected informality in internal chat interactions allows users to connect with less friction and more personally.
  • Chats are often short discussions and are also commonly escalated to voice, video or content sharing interactions to more efficiently convey complex information.
  • Email provides a forum to share information more formally and to easily add/delete participants, including external parties, included in the conversation.
  • Video calling and conferencing provides the benefits of eye contact and body language that enrich interactions through personalization and visual cues.

Frost & Sullivan data show that, by the end of 2026, 95% of organizations will have adopted video conferencing and 94% will have adopted team spaces/group chat. In the same timeframe, 94% of organizations will increase or maintain their investments in voice calling and private branch exchange (PBX) functionality.

The fundamental value propositions of unified communications have not changed: an integrated set of multimodal communications capabilities reduces app switching, enables more seamless interactions, and increases productivity. Frost & Sullivan ITDM surveys find that the vast majority, 83%, of organizations prefer to buy a fully integrated unified communications and collaboration (UCC) solution that includes meetings, messaging, and calling.

With UCC adoption now widespread and still growing, the urgency to implement the right tools in the intensely competitive and rapidly evolving landscape has significantly increased. Forward-thinking organizations see greater potential impact from their communications investments and demand next-level value for their business and workforce. Among ITDMs who participated in Frost & Sullivan’s survey, 78% invest in UCC to boost team collaboration and 76% invest to improve the customer experience, attract the best talent, and improve employee engagement and satisfaction.

With its AI-powered portfolio spanning platforms, devices and workspaces, Cisco is uniquely positioned in the business communications market to execute on its Distance Zero vision. By committing resources, prioritizing powerful partnerships and listening to customer input, Cisco consistently delivers innovations that allow unified communications to unleash greater value across customer environments and their workforces.

Frost & Sullivan research validates numerous other industry sources that indicate employee net promoter scores (eNPS) are key drivers of both elevated customer satisfaction and significant revenue growth. Therefore, business leaders should embrace the concept of Distance Zero, the tools that facilitate it, and the resulting employee connectedness that can instill a culture of helpfulness, inclusion, collaboration, and productivity to empower individuals, teams, and the entire organizations to maximize their performance.

Learn more: 

  • Get in touch with us
  • Join us for weekly live demos of our latest workspace experiences
  • The new workplace: powered by AI and Collaboration Devices

About Frost & Sullivan

A passionate focus on sustainable growth.

Since our founding, Frost & Sullivan has sharpened its focus into a passionate commitment to growth. Why growth? Because in the absence of growth, we don’t just stand still but move backward. Growth is an essential business objective of any organization that seeks to thrive, not just survive. Our moral imperative of growth commands us to create sustainable, manageable Growth Opportunities that increase revenue and market share while contributing to the well-being of the world in which we live.

We have proven strategies and implementation best practices that help our customers overcome challenges and identify new opportunities for transformational growth. In addition, we have over 1,000 experts who have covered virtually every industry and trend for decades, so we can hit the ground running with a deep understanding of our client’s sectors and Growth Opportunities they may not even be aware of.

Frost & Sullivan’s global team is organized around three main drivers of corporate growth: Vision & Strategy, Brand & Demand, and Emerging Technologies. We’ve used these three value propositions to design our Growth Councils, Growth Workshops, and Growth Pipeline Dialogs to help our customers identify and maintain their very own Growth Pipeline.

item.title: How to build a winning digital customer experience strategy in 2025.
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the forefront of digital innovation, where customer experience (CX) is not just a component of your business strategy but the very heartbeat of success in 2025. As the world becomes increasingly interconnected, businesses must evolve to meet the demands of a digital-first audience. It’s no longer just about having an online presence—it’s about creating a seamless, engaging, and personalized journey for every customer interaction, whether through a dynamic website, vibrant social media channels, or intuitive mobile apps.

In this blog, we’ll explore the cutting-edge strategies that will redefine how you engage with your customers online, ensuring your brand stands out in an ever-competitive digital landscape. Join us as we delve into the essential elements of building a transformative digital customer experience that captivates and retains your audience.

What is a digital customer experience?

Digital customer experience refers to the interactions customers have with a brand through digital channels, such as websites, mobile apps, social media platforms, email, live chat, and other online touchpoints. It encompasses every digital interaction throughout the entire customer journey, from discovering a product or service to making a purchase, seeking support, and beyond.

Well-executed digital CX combines technology, usability, accessibility, personalization, and efficiency to ensure customers can achieve their goals with ease and satisfaction. It’s a key component of a broader customer experience strategy—especially as more interactions shift to digital platforms.

What does a positive digital CX look like?

A seamless digital customer experience calls for engaging and personalized interactions that leave them feeling valued and satisfied. Here are the characteristics of a positive digital CX:

  • Seamless omnichannel integration: Effortless interactions across multiple platforms help reduce friction and improve customer satisfaction.
  • User-friendly design: Simple, intuitive interfaces across digital touchpoints enhance accessibility and encourage engagement. When users can navigate easily, they may be more likely to complete desired actions.
  • Tailored experiences: Personalizing content, recommendations, and interactions makes users feel valued and understood, which can convert them into repeat customers.
  • Speed and efficiency: Customers expect quick resolutions and seamless interactions. Fast-loading pages and responsive service reduce frustration.

Why is your digital CX strategy important?

Creating an effective digital experience isn’t an ancillary component of modern business but one that requires its own strategy entirely—especially when the benefits of getting digital CX right are so valuable:

Gain a competitive advantage in the marketplace.

A strong digital CX strategy sets your brand apart in crowded markets by delivering superior experiences. Innovative digital touchpoints, such as AI-driven personalization or immersive virtual experiences, can become unique selling points.

Real-time customer engagement.

Many digital tools enable instant or near-instant communication with customers through live chat, notifications, or real-time updates. Immediate responses to customer inquiries or issues work to enhance trust and satisfaction.

Increased revenue opportunities and customer retention.

Providing personalized recommendations and targeted promotions creates upselling and cross-selling opportunities. Satisfied customers are more likely to make repeat purchases and advocate for your brand, driving long-term revenue growth.

Personalized digital experiences also foster stronger emotional connections with customers, which is a critical step for increasing brand loyalty and customer retention.

Enable broader accessibility.

Digital strategies allow customers to interact with your brand anytime and anywhere, catering to diverse needs and schedules. Features like chatbots and mobile-optimized interfaces make it easier for customers to get the help they need when they need it.

Improved efficiency and cost savings.

Automating routine tasks like answering FAQs or processing transactions reduces operational costs. Digital tools optimize workflows, allowing teams to focus on higher-value tasks and strategic initiatives.

Data-driven decision-making.

Digital interactions generate valuable insights into customer behavior, preferences, and pain points. A digital CX strategy uses analytics to inform product development, marketing campaigns, and customer service improvements.

How to design a digital customer experience strategy

Before adopting new technologies or signing up for another social media account, set clear goals and understand the state of your current digital CX. Completing these steps ahead of designing a new strategy ensures that you focus on your most important action items and areas for improvement first.

1: Define clear objectives.

What do you hope to achieve by building a better overall customer experience? Whether you’re looking to improve customer satisfaction, increase retention, reduce support costs, or drive revenue, choose one or two specific goals and focus your efforts there. Then, detail how you will achieve those goals and track progress in depth. Trying to achieve too many goals at once can slow progression.

2: Audit your existing digital experience.

Conduct a thorough audit of your existing digital channels, including your website, mobile app, social media, chatbots, and more. How do they perform? And, perhaps more importantly, how do your customers and employees feel about them? Gather feedback from both parties to identify gaps and areas for enhancement.

3: Understand your target audience.

Depending on the demographic of your target audience, they may prefer certain technologies or channels over others. Before developing detailed personas, identify all digital touchpoints and interactions customers currently have with your brand and highlight friction points and opportunities for improvement.

When it’s time to build personas, be as detailed as possible, highlighting key demographics, behaviors, preferences, and pain points to inform your digital CX strategy and focus on areas that are most important for your audience.

4: Prioritize omnichannel integration.

Enabling seamless transitions between channels is a core function of frictionless digital CX. Customers and agents should be able to transition from mobile to desktop or from chatbot to human agent quickly and easily without dissolving any progress.

Use a unified digital platform or tools to centralize customer data and interactions, creating a consistent experience that enables a cohesive customer journey.

5: Train and empower employees.

Having the right technology in place for effective digital CX is great, but only so far as your employees know how to use it. Provide staff with tools and training that not only teach them how to use the technology but empower them to deliver excellent digital experiences. Then, extend that practice across your organization to foster a culture that prioritizes customer-centricity and innovation.

6. Collect and analyze customer data.

Surveys, social media listening, and customer feedback forms capture valuable customer insights. Once you know how they feel or what they want, leverage analytics tools to track performance metrics (e.g., Net Promoter Score (NPS), Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAAT), and Customer Effort Score(CES)) and identify improvement areas. When it’s time to deliver, use customer data to create tailored experiences, such as personalized product recommendations, targeted marketing, and relevant content.

Best practices for maintaining a great customer experience

Once you’ve designed a digital strategy to enhance user experience that aligns with your business goals and your customer’s preferences, these digital CX best practices can help you keep it running smoothly.

Leverage AI-powered virtual assistants.

Artificial intelligence, and generative AI in particular, has come a long way since its spike in popularity. Top AI tools enhance your agent’s capabilities to deliver great customer service, faster. Cisco AI Assistant, for example, automatically summarizes customer interactions and suggests ideal responses to save time and boost satisfaction.

AI can also analyze customer tone and emotion in real-time during interactions, providing agents with key insights that enable them to adapt to that situation, which could mean changing their approach to improve outcomes.

Implement self-service tools.

Deploying conversational AI as a self-service option to handle routine customer inquiries provides instant and effective responses and helps reduce the workload on your human agents. Less time spent on ordinary or common questions means agents can focus on more complex problem-solving.

Knowledge bases, community forums, or virtual agents are also great options for customer self-service that allows them to resolve issues independently.

Practice workforce optimization.

Lastly, effective workforce optimization enhances the customer and employee experience simultaneously by enabling or supporting most core functions of your customer service. Equip employees with advanced tools to help manage workloads, access critical customer insights, and reduce stress. A properly-optimized workforce enables agents to deliver their best service.

Strengthen your digital CX strategy with Webex.

Get and stay ahead of digital transformation. Explore Webex Customer Experience Solutions and start building a better digital CX that drives engagement and gives agents the tools they need to deliver top-notch service.

item.title: RTP Transmission: Coping with Real Networks
item.content:encoded:
In the previous blog we introduced the RTP format. In this blog, we will cover how RTP packets are sent across networks in the real world, and some of the challenges that can follow. 

RTP Transmission

While most internet traffic is TCP-based, real-time media is generally sent over UDP instead. There are some key differences between TCP and UDP:

UDP over TCP

When comparing TCP to UDP in the chart above, we see that UDP is a much simpler protocol, with none of the feedback and acknowledgement that makes TCP reliable and ordered. This means that media sent over UDP will generally have a significantly lower latency than TCP, so in cases where latency in important UDP is used in preference to TCP, even though doing so introduces significant complexity, coping with the lossy, out-of-order nature of UDP (see the Resilience section when it becomes available). TCP may still be used as a fallback if UDP is unavailable and may be used preferentially in cases where latency requirements are less stringent, such as unidirectional streaming over platforms such as Facebook Live.

Due to the connectionless nature of UDP there is a risk that firewalls or NATs will block the media. The most robust solution to this problem is a set of techniques called Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE), which may be covered in a later blog series.

However, one simple way to mitigate this issue is through symmetric ports –implementations should send RTP for a media stream on the same port as it uses to receive the media. The reason for this is that most NATs and firewalls, when sending outgoing traffic, will also temporarily allow incoming traffic on the same port, and route it back to the IP address of the sender within the firewall. These temporarily open ports are known as ‘pinholes’. When debugging, if bidirectional streams such as main audio and video work, but unidirectional streams such as content video fail, the culprit is often a NAT or firewall allowing the bidirectional streams through due to pinholing while blocking the unidirectional stream which does not have an open pinhole.

Implementations normally assign ports dynamically at the point of use from within the ephemeral port range. RFC6335 recommends the use of 49152-65535 for dynamic ephemeral ports. Though use of this port range is quite common, others may use the Linux port range of 32768-60999 or some other range. The port range should generally be configurable by administrators to allow them to comply with enterprise policy. However, for cloud-based services that are accessible to many customers, it is recommended to use a considerably narrower range as many enterprises dislike opening access to a large number of external ports for security or policy reasons. If possible, in such cases, it is best to offer support for using only a single, consistent port for all traffic via multiplexing to minimise the ports an enterprise must open.

When multiplexing is not in use, each media stream in each concurrent call requires its own port, along with a port for RTCP. By convention these are usually a pair, with RTP on an even-numbered port and RTCP on the port numbered one higher. When binding these pairs, one simple technique is to bind a UDP socket within the dynamic range without specifying a port, and once that succeeds, attempt to bind the port one higher (if the port bound initially is even) or one lower (if the port bound is odd). If the second bind fails, which should only happen if another application is contending with the port range, the initial port should be released and a new one tried until a pair is successfully bound, or some upper limit of attempts is reached.

Note that, according to the rules of Offer/Answer SDP (RFC3264), as soon as an implementation has sent an SDP they should be ready to receive any of the media streams that SDP advertises support for. Indeed, because the media path is normally simpler and faster than the signalling path, it is more common than not for media packets to begin arriving prior to the SDP Answer or ACK. For unencrypted media, the implementation should ideally begin rendering the media as soon as it is received. This is often not possible with encrypted media because the encryption keys will not have been received yet, but at the very least the system should receive the packets and discard them gracefully until they can be handled, while not generating indications such as ICMP unreachable responses.

Sending RTP Packets

Packet sizes and MTU

UDP packets have a maximum size, known as the Maximum Transmission Unit, or MTU. However, rather than be a standard value, different network links will have different maximums. In practical terms, the smallest MTU for any hop along a given path determines the path MTU.

It is particularly important to ensure that RTP packets do not exceed the path MTU. If IPv4 is in use then packets that exceed the path MTU may be fragmented, and may be re-assembled automatically before being delivered to the far end, but IP fragmentation is notoriously unreliable for a range of implementation and security reasons (see RFC8900: “IP Fragmentation Considered Fragile” for more details) and oversized packets are quite likely to never be received at their intended destination. However, the lower the MTU the greater the overheads imposed by packet headers relative to the RTP payload data, and the less efficient transmission will become, so the closer to the maximum packets can be the better.

Unfortunately, while there are techniques for automatic discovery of the Path MTU (Path MTU Discovery, or PMTUD) they are not always effective, and will delay the start of media if run first. As such, most implementations rely on a configurable MTU with a relatively conservative default that can be overridden by the user or admin. The widely-supported upper limit for ethernet packets is 1500 bytes (meaning a maximum RTP packet size of 1472 bytes given a minimum 20 byte IP header size and the 8 byte UDP header), but as some network hops may introduce additional overheads or have somewhat lower limits; 1400 is generally the default for devices designed for enterprise networks, while implementations looking for maximum interoperability go even lower: Chrome currently uses a max RTP packet size of 1200 for WebRTC, for instance.

Packet Pacing

Note that, while the maximum size of an RTP packet is less than 1.5kB, media frames can, and will, be split across RTP packets; it is not uncommon for video keyframes to be split across dozens or even hundreds of packets. Exactly how this is done is dependent on the codec and factors such as, in H.264, the packetization mode. In contrast, audio frames are much smaller and will generally fit within a single packet. Indeed, some implementations include multiple audio frames in a single packet to save bandwidth by reducing the overhead per frame, though this will increase latency since the first frame cannot be sent until the subsequent frames in the packet are sampled and encoded, and hence this technique is usually not worth the bandwidth savings.

However, the consequence of having frames split across a large number of packets leads to a need for packet pacing. The simplest implementation of real-time media just puts packets onto the wire as soon as the encoder produces them, but this can be problematic for video, particularly at higher resolutions, where keyframes or periods of sudden change can lead to frames that involve hundreds of RTP packets. Sending all the packets in a sudden burst can temporarily and greatly exceed the negotiated bandwidth limits, which can congest the network and lead to buffer bloat or packet loss. 

Packet pacing often involves adding a small FIFO buffer after the encoder to pace out the packets onto the wire in a more uniform fashion to mitigate this burstiness. There are a number of ways this can be implemented; one common pattern is a leaky bucket algorithm which allows control over bandwidth and burstiness. Each media stream can be paced independently, or there can be a single buffer combining multiple egress streams; this will be more complex to implement but can be designed to ensure that smaller streams such as audio are given priority when there is high contention. Note that, rather than a native implementation, some services use the Linux tc (traffic control) module to enable packet pacing.

Quality of Service (QoS)

One further step than can be taken to improve reliability and latency is setting appropriate Quality of Service (QoS) markings on packets. QoS is the practise of allowing routers and switches to classify traffic so as to appropriately prioritise it. In real-time media, this is generally done using Differentiated Service CodePoint (DSCP) markings as defined in RFC2474, which is a field of 6 bits in the IP header that help routers and switches classify the type of traffic within the packet.

Implementations will not generally need to worry about the mechanisms of DiffServ or writing the IP packet header, which will normally be handled at a lower level; the important part for real-time media implementation is choosing appropriate values for streams and ensuring these are set on the sockets on which the packets are being sent.

There are several RFCs that discuss how to best mark various packet flows (RFC4594 generally, RFC8837 in the context of WebRTC specifically). They generally recommend that the highest level of priority and latency-intolerance is assigned to the audio stream, which they recommend marking for Expedited Forwarding (EF) with a value of 46, while video should be marked for Assured Forwarding (AF) with a value of 34 (for AF41), with lower values for other packet flows. Many implementations follow these recommendations, though it is also recommended that any implementation targeted for use by larger enterprises allows admins to configure these values, as they may have their own specific QoS policies they want all their applications to follow.

It is possible to set DSCP at a more fine-grained level, applying different markings to different packets within a given media stream depending on their specific payload, such as applying lower DSCP values for packets encoding discardable layers in H.264 streams encoded with temporal or spatial scalability; however, few implementations go this far.

It is worth noting that the common practise of setting different levels of QoS for audio and video can lead them to take different paths through the network, causing them to arrive out of sync, and requiring delay of one to achieve lipsync with the other (see the next blog on lipsync for more details). As such, there are those who argue that if an audio and video stream are meant to be synchronised, they should have the same DSCP markings applied, to try and minimise differential delay between the streams, rather than marking audio as more important/delay-intolerant than its matching video.

item.title: Pioneering Healthcare Transformation: Insights and Innovations ...
item.content:encoded:
This week, our team heads to Las Vegas for the 2025 HIMSS Global Health Conference & Exhibition—a hub for healthcare innovators exploring the latest digital health advancements. At the heart of this innovation is the power of technology to improve patient care, streamline operations, and enhance collaboration across the healthcare ecosystem.

That’s why we’re proud to spotlight three 2024 Webex Customer Award winners and finalists whose work embodies these goals. By harnessing AI and advanced communication tools, these leaders are transforming how healthcare organizations connect, collaborate, and care for their communities.

1. How Cigna leverages Webex and AI to transform hybrid work and healthcare

With more than 70,000 employees and $180.5 billion in annual revenue, The Cigna Group operates on a massive scale. After the pandemic shifted how work gets done, Cigna turned to the Webex Suite to support its hybrid work strategy—creating a more connected, flexible environment for its global workforce. This isn’t just about video meetings; it’s about fostering collaboration that drives better patient and employee outcomes.

Now, Cigna’s Center of Excellence is taking things further by preparing to roll out Cisco AI Assistant for Webex. Features like Meeting Summaries will cut down on administrative work, allowing teams to focus on high-impact initiatives. For an organization managing the complexities of global healthcare delivery, these improvements translate to faster decisions, smoother collaboration, and ultimately, better care for the communities Cigna serves.

2. Burrell Behavioral Health revolutionizes crisis support with Webex

In the world of behavioral health services, effective communication can be a lifeline. Burrell Behavioral Health exemplifies this by impacting over 60,000 clients annually across the Midwest. With over two million calls managed every year, including critical interactions through the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, Burrell recognized the need for a robust and scalable communication system to support its growing demands.

The necessity for an advanced communication infrastructure became even more pressing following a significant merger, which expanded Burrell’s workforce from 1,500 to 5,000 employees. This expansion required a centralized system that could maintain high efficiency and reliability across the board.

Enter Webex Contact Center and Webex Calling—technological solutions that have transformed Burrell’s operations. By integrating these platforms, Burrell achieved an impressive 99.9% uptime, ensuring seamless collaboration and communication within its expanded team. This technological shift was crucial in supporting Burrell’s mission to provide immediate and reliable crisis support.

The launch of the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline marked a pivotal moment for Burrell. This initiative guarantees clients have direct access to crisis support workers when they need it most. The centralized administration offered by Webex Control Hub provides Burrell with vital analytics, helping the organization understand staffing needs and optimize resource allocation during high-demand periods.

Incorporating Cisco AI Assistant into their system has further enhanced Burrell’s capabilities. Advanced call routing and real-time insights allow the organization to scale efficiently, maintaining a client satisfaction rate of over 90%. This technological edge ensures that Burrell can meet the demands of their clients effectively and promptly. By embracing innovative solutions, Burrell not only meets the immediate needs of its clients but also sets a benchmark for effective crisis support in the future.

Read the full Burrell Behavioral Health story here.

3. Mercalis Enhances Life Sciences Customer Experience with AI-Driven Webex Solutions

Serving over 500 life sciences companies and supporting 36 million patients, Mercalis plays a vital role in connecting people to the healthcare solutions they need. As the company continues to expand, it recognized the need to evolve its customer experience approach to meet growing demands.

With 1,000 contact center agents managing more than 400,000 monthly calls, the organization faces unique challenges—especially during peak seasons like New Year’s re-enrollment, when call volumes can double overnight. To address this, Mercalis relies heavily on technology to support and enhance service delivery.

To handle these demands, Mercalis transitioned to Webex Contact Center’s cloud-based platform. The switch wasn’t just about handling more calls—it was about delivering a higher quality experience. AI tools and features like Topic Analytics and conversation summaries help agents resolve issues faster and provide more personalized support. Meanwhile, the centralized management portal, Webex Control Hub, provides intuitive dashboards and real-time performance data, making it easier for technical resources to maintain systems and for agents to deliver excellent customer support.

Looking ahead, Mercalis plans to leverage sentiment analysis and advanced call summarization to further refine customer interactions. By tapping into these AI tools, they’re setting a new standard for patient support in the life sciences industry.

Read their case study here.

Charting the future of healthcare transformation.

As the 2025 HIMSS Global Health Conference & Exhibition wraps up, one thing is clear: healthcare’s future will be shaped by organizations willing to embrace change. The 2024 Webex Customer Award winners and finalists—Cigna, Burrell Behavioral Health, and Mercalis—exemplify how technology, when thoughtfully applied, can drive transformative results. From making hybrid work more effective to ensuring critical crisis support is always available and enhancing patient experiences, these innovators are setting the pace for what’s next in healthcare.

Their commitment to digital transformation isn’t just about adopting new tools—it’s about solving real-world challenges that directly impact patient care and operational efficiency. By combining human ingenuity with cutting-edge technology, these trailblazers are creating a more resilient, patient-centered healthcare system. Their success stories are a reminder of what’s possible when innovation, collaboration, and purpose come together.

Here’s to the healthcare leaders pushing boundaries, inspiring progress, and shaping a healthier, more connected world.

item.title: Announcing the new Epic integration for Webex Contact Center, ...
item.content:encoded:
At Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS) 2025, we’re excited to announce the upcoming beta of Webex Contact Center’s integration with Epic’s industry-leading electronic health record (EHR) software.

Developed through the Epic Toolbox program, this new cutting-edge integration equips contact center agents and care providers with Webex’s multi-channel communication platform within Epic Systems (Cheers/Hyperdrive). Using a single user interface, native within Epic, agents will have all essential patient, provider, caregiver, and member medical information and the ability to effortlessly manage interactions at their fingertips, providing streamlined, hyper-personalized, and empathetic support to every interaction.

This collaboration with Epic is part of the Webex Customer Experience portfolio’s strategy to seamlessly bring together proactive journeys, AI Agents, and human agents to transform patient experiences. By bridging intelligent automation and human expertise, we are dedicated to enabling a connected healthcare journey, setting new standards for efficiency, engagement, and quality of care for the healthcare industry.

A deeper look at the Epic integration for Webex Contact Center

Epic Systems is a leading healthcare software company that provides electronic health record (EHR) solutions that streamline healthcare operations. It’s relied upon by more than 600,000 physicians and millions of healthcare workers, accessing over 305 million patient records—covering 60% of the U.S. population.

The new Epic integration for Webex Contact Center empowers agents with a seamless, feature-rich communication platform integrated directly into the Epic Cheers/Hyperdrive user interface.

Healthcare providers can streamline interactions across the entire care journey—from access and diagnosis to treatment and recovery. Agents can efficiently manage conversations across the preferred channel directly within Epic, eliminating the need to switch between windows or tools, making it easier to engage with every patient.

Agents can seamlessly leverage all the advanced features of Webex Contact Center, including Call Hub screen pop, instant call transfers, ready-to-use templates for quick and consistent responses, and interaction histories for context-aware service—all within a single, intuitive interface.

The integration also brings the full power of the AI-driven Webex Contact Center to agents within their Epic interface. Some highlight features include:

  • Routing and queue management: Patient-centric routing strategies leverage historical experiences to match with the best available agent. Agent availability and skill sets are accurately matched with patient priority, value, and needs.
  • Seamless omnichannel interaction handling: Support for voice, email, messaging and chat channels all within a single task pane.
  • Reporting and dashboards: Access to historical and real-time data make it easy to analyze, understand and manage patient/provider/caregiver/member interactions and agent activity.

Agents and supervisors can also leverage the Webex Contact Center AI Assistant to operate a smarter, more efficient contact center. Please note that some features will be available at a later date as we continue to enhance the Webex Contact Center integration with Epic.

  • AI Agent Transfer Context Summaries: Facilitate seamless handoffs from AI agents and IVR transfers to human agents, ensuring patients do not need to repeat themselves.
  • Dropped Call Summaries: Ensure continuity after a point of disconnection by capturing and documenting interaction details to seamlessly resume a conversation with all the previous context.
  • Automatic CSAT Scoring: This solution leverages operational data and transcripts to evaluate 100% of voice interactions, effectively overcoming the challenge of low patient survey response rates. This capability will be extended to also delve deeper to help train and coach agents.
  • Agent Wellbeing: Agent Wellbeing automatically identifies signs of burnout in real time, providing insights that enable proactive actions such as automatic breaks, schedule changes, and capacity management across channels.
  • Topic Analytics: This analytics feature uses historical data to help users quickly identify the reasons for incoming calls and analyze them to enable proactive action such as training, FAQs, or process updates.
  • Real-time transcripts for agents: Provide agents with a live, continuously updated transcript of conversations directly within the Agent Desktop. This ensures that every spoken word is accurately captured in real time, reducing the risk of missed details and misunderstandings. Agents can follow along effortlessly without the need for manual notetaking, allowing them to stay fully engaged in the conversation.

By leveraging the latest AI advancements to help agents work smarter, Webex Contact Center empowers agents to resolve issues more efficiently, enhance productivity, and minimize burnout. With AI-driven automation handling routine tasks and providing real-time assistance, agents proactively focus on delivering high-quality human support.

Elevate engagement and self-service with Webex Connect and Webex AI Agent

To assist further with elevating patient engagement and care, healthcare providers can leverage Webex Connect, which is accessible through the Epic Connection Hub.

Driven by EHR data and real-time events, Webex Connect enables healthcare providers to automate proactive communications for proven out-of-the-box use cases such as patient onboarding, annual open enrollment, interaction surveys, appointment reminders, chronic care notifications, billing notifications, and post-discharge support across multiple channels. These carefully orchestrated interactions ensure patients stay engaged, adhere to their care plans, keep their appointments, and feel supported throughout the entirety of their healthcare journey. What’s more, these interactions are delivered utilizing patient preferred rich, branded messaging which instills trust and instant brand recognition with every patient communication.

Carefully orchestrated proactive communications serve as the perfect entry point for patient self-service.

Webex AI Agent enables patients to respond to proactive communications and reach out to access 24/7 on-demand healthcare. Hospitals, clinics, and healthcare providers can enable an intelligent digital front door, allowing patients to self-serve to access information and services effortlessly. AI Agents operate in asynchronous mode, utilizing agentic AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) for dynamic dialogue and context management, or in scripted mode, leveraging Natural Language Understanding (NLU) to recognize intent and follow structured workflows.

Whether patients need to reschedule an appointment, check symptoms, receive preliminary health advice, manage prescriptions, or handle billing and payments, Webex AI Agent provides instant, scalable on-demand support across the patient-preferred channels. For more complex inquiries or when a patient prefers human assistance, the Webex AI Agent ensures a seamless, context-aware transition to a human agent, maintaining conversation history to provide seamless communication between the patient and Webex AI agent to the human agent without repetition.

Talk to us about a seamless patient experience strategy at HIMSS 2025

Cisco’s collaboration with Epic Systems shows how integrating advanced communication tools within EHR platforms leads to better patient outcomes and creates a fully connected healthcare experience. The Webex Customer Experience portfolio showcases our cohesive approach to fostering trust, loyalty and efficiency in healthcare.

To explore how we help you turn your patient experience goals into reality, visit us at our Patient Experience Kiosk (booth 1227) at HIMSS 2025 in Las Vegas, Nevada.

item.title: How do call centers work, and how do they compare to contact centers?
item.content:encoded:
Call centers have been around since the 1960s and have continued to operate in much the same way.

It wasn’t until the introduction of instant messaging and other faster, more convenient means of communication that the call center formula began to move forward.

These days, businesses use both call centers and contact centers—but what are the key differences between these two customer service solutions, which is better suited for your business, and why?

What is a call center?

A call center is a centralized office or facility equipped to handle a large volume of incoming and outgoing telephone calls, typically for customer service, technical support, sales, or other inquiries. They’re typically staffed by trained agents who communicate with customers or clients over the phone to address their concerns, provide information, resolve issues, or complete transactions.

Today’s call centers use the following protocols and technologies in their day-to-day operations:

  • Call routing: The automated process of directing incoming calls to the appropriate call center representative or department based on predefined criteria, such as caller ID, input selections, or center agent availability.
  • Interactive Voice Response (IVR) systems: The utilization of pre-recorded or dynamically generated voice prompts, combined with voice recognition and touch-tone inputs, to interact with callers, collect relevant information, and route calls to appropriate agents or departments—all based on predefined logic and integration with backend databases.
  • Queuing: A system that manages incoming calls by placing them in a line and distributing them to available agents based on priority rules and current workload.
  • Agent assignment: The method by which incoming calls are allocated to specific customer service representatives based on factors like skill set, availability, and call priority.
  • Centralized documentation: The systematic recording of customer interactions, issues, resolutions, and other relevant data within a centralized database.
  • Reporting and analysis: The generation and examination of data and metrics related to call center operations to assess performance, identify trends, and inform strategic decision-making.

The specific technologies and policies that a call center uses will change slightly depending on its type. An inbound call center handles incoming calls from customers seeking support, information, or services. These centers focus on addressing customer inquiries, providing technical assistance, processing orders, and managing customer relationships.

An outbound call center proactively reaches out to customers for sales, telemarketing, surveys, and market research. These centers are dedicated to generating leads, promoting products or services, and conducting customer outreach initiatives. A blended call center combines both inbound and outbound call handling within the same facility. This setup allows agents to manage incoming support requests while also making proactive outbound calls.

A virtual call center—or remote call center—operates with agents working remotely from various locations instead of a centralized physical office. Utilizing cloud-based call center technology, virtual operations offer flexibility, reduce overhead costs, and enable businesses to scale their operations efficiently.

An outsourced call center delegates customer service operations to a third-party provider, allowing businesses to leverage specialized expertise while reducing operational costs. In contrast, an in-house call center is managed and operated directly by the company, with all agents employed as internal staff. Some business leaders believe this approach allows for greater control over operations, call center training, and quality assurance, ensuring that the call center aligns closely with the company’s values and objectives.

Lastly, a specialized call center focuses on serving specific industries or handling particular types of inquiries. Common examples include healthcare call centers, technical support centers, or financial services centers—each requiring agents to have industry-specific skills and understanding.

Benefits of having a call center.

From improved customer service and increased efficiency to cost savings, enhanced data collection, and more, the benefits of having a call center are both numerous and essential.

Improved customer service

A call center provides a reliable way for customers to get the help they need when they need it.

Skilled agents are available to answer questions, resolve issues, and provide information—making sure that customers feel supported and valued. Dedicated, easily accessible assistance leads to improved customer satisfaction and can strengthen loyalty, as customers not only need but appreciate having a direct line of support.

Increased efficiency

Call centers are purpose-built to handle large volumes of calls.

With technologies like automatic call distribution (ACD) and IVR systems, calls are quickly directed to the right agents based on their expertise and availability. Such next-generation technologies are particularly important as, beyond their ability to increase efficiency, over eight in 10 customers (81%) say personalized support is an absolute necessity.

Reduced costs

Operating a call center can be more cost-effective than managing multiple smaller support teams.

By centralizing customer service operations, businesses can reduce expenses related to infrastructure, technology, and staffing. This is particularly true for cloud-based solutions, due to their scalable infrastructure that allows businesses to:

  • Adjust resources based on demand without significant upfront investments.
  • Benefit from pay-as-you-go pricing models.
  • Gain access to automatic software updates and maintenance handled by the service provider.
  • Support the ability to integrate seamlessly with other cloud-based tools and platforms.

Enhanced data collection and analysis

Call centers are excellent sources of valuable customer data. Every interaction is recorded and stored, providing business leaders and agents insights into customer preferences, common issues, and overall behavior.

Particularly through a customer relationship management (CRM) platform, call centers can meticulously categorize data and link it to individual customer profiles. Moreover, advanced analytics tools within the CRM allow for detailed analysis of call trends, such as:

  • Peak contact times.
  • Recurring issues.
  • Shifts in customer sentiment.

AI-driven CRM granular insight empowers managers to implement more than just targeted training programs, but also develop tailored solutions that address specific customer needs.

Scalability

Scalability is at the heart of modern call center platforms.

As cloud-based call center software becomes the norm, business leaders can benefit from the capacity to scale up or down without the limitations of physical infrastructure. That way, operational leaders can ensure that customer service remains consistent and effective, no matter the business’ evolution.

Call center vs. contact center: 3 key differences.

There’s some overlap between call center and contact center operations. Ultimately, distinguishing between the two means considering their scope of communication and focus on customer experience (CX). It also means taking into account the specific functionality that each offers.

1. Scope of communication

Call centers are mostly focused on handling voice calls, serving as the main point of contact for customers who prefer to speak directly with a representative. In contrast, contact centers expand the scope of communication by incorporating multiple channels beyond just voice calls. They manage emails, live chats, social media messages, SMS, and even video calls—providing customers with various ways to reach out based on their individual preferences.

2. Focus on CX

While both call centers and contact centers aim to deliver excellent customer service, contact centers place a stronger emphasis on providing a comprehensive omnichannel customer experience. This means ensuring consistency, continuity, and convenience across all communication channels. Contact centers prioritize creating a seamless journey for customers, where their interactions are interconnected and personalized regardless of the channel used.

Call centers focus on resolving issues and handling inquiries via voice interactions. While they strive for high customer satisfaction, the lack of integration with other channels can result in a less cohesive overall experience.

3. Functionality

Typically, contact center platforms offer increased functionality over their call center counterparts. They offer unique capabilities that call centers often lack, such as:

  • Omnichannel routing engines: Contact centers utilize sophisticated algorithms and real-time data to intelligently route customer interactions across various channels based on factors like contact center agent skill set, current load, and customer preference.
  • AI-driven chatbots and virtual assistants: Contact centers employ natural language processing and conversational AI algorithms to perform a variety of otherwise time-consuming tasks, such as booking appointments, processing orders, troubleshooting technical issues, and managing account inquiries. These AI tools can escalate interactions to human agents when necessary.
  • Social media management tools: Contact centers integrate with leading social media channels using APIs to monitor, analyze, and respond to customer interactions in real-time. Their features include sentiment analysis, automated tagging, and engagement tracking.
  • Interactive Voice Response (IVR) with multi-channel capabilities: Advanced IVR systems not only manage voice call routing but also initiate follow-up interactions through preferred digital channels.
  • Predictive analytics: Contact centers utilize big data technologies and machine learning models to analyze interaction patterns, forecast demand, and generate actionable insights. Centralized contact center platforms provide dashboards with key decision-making metrics, such as customer satisfaction scores, first contact resolution rates, and agent performance indicators.

Next-generation contact center solutions also offer robust APIs and software development kits (SDKs) that enable seamless integration with third-party applications, custom channel additions, and bespoke workflow automation. This flexibility allows contact centers to tailor their technology stack to specific business needs and rapidly adapt to emerging communication trends.

How to know when your business needs a next-generation call or contact center solution

Call and contact centers adopt next-generation solutions for various reasons: enhanced customer self-support, unified internal collaboration, enhanced scalability, improved data security, and more.

In the case of First Horizon Bank, the adoption of Webex Contact Center increased the bank’s customer self-service rate to 87%. The increase allowed the bank to reallocate its 750 agents to address more complex customer issues.

item.title: The role of CRM in contact centers in 2025.
item.content:encoded:
In today’s fast-paced world, customer expectations are higher than ever. To meet these demands, contact centers and call centers are turning to innovative solutions like CRM systems. These advanced platforms empower agents to deliver personalized, efficient support, ensuring customer satisfaction and loyalty. Without the ability to provide quick and contextual service, call centers risk losing customers to competitors.

Discover how embracing cloud-based CRM technology can transform your call center operations and enhance the customer experience.

What is CRM software, and why is it important?

CRM software is a technology solution that helps businesses manage, analyze, and optimize interactions with current and potential customers throughout the customer journey.

They’re a centralized platform—or repository—where organizations can store and access all customer-related information, from contact details and interaction history to purchase records, preferences, and feedback. Next-generation CRM systems take this even further by offering AI-driven records, including sentiment, behavior predictions, and personalized recommendations.

CRM software: an overview.

CRM software acts as a specialized tool that equips agents with comprehensive, easily accessible customer information. Call centers either integrate individual third-party CRM systems into their existing workflows or adopt an internal unified platform that adopts CRM capabilities.

Here’s how call center and contact center CRM software functions, in practice. When receiving a call, the CRM system uses the caller’s phone number (Caller ID) to retrieve their profile from the database. This process, known as screen popping, displays the customer’s information on the agent’s screen before they answer the call—providing immediate context.

The agent can then interact with a unified CRM dashboard that acts as a consolidation of all relevant customer information. CRM dashboards typically include:

  • Customer profile: Personal details, contact information, and account status.
  • Current issues: Open tickets, pending requests, and ongoing cases.
  • Performance metrics: Real-time indicators such as call duration, hold times, and service level agreements (SLAs).

When a first-time caller reaches out, the CRM system guides the agent through collecting essential information, such as the caller’s name, contact details, and the reason for their call. As the agent enters this information into the CRM database, it creates a new customer profile that then informs future interactions.

For new and repeat callers alike, the CRM manages the lifecycle of each ticket, from creation to closure. It ensures that call center agents address tickets within designated timeframes and facilitates communication between different teams involved in resolving the issue. Moreover, CRM systems often incorporate a searchable knowledge base containing FAQs, troubleshooting guides, product information, and company policies.

Why a CRM platform is important: 6 benefits for contact centers.

As business leaders implement CRM software in their contact center or call center operations, they open the door to a multitude of benefits—from enhanced customer experiences and improved agent productivity to gaining actionable data-driven insights that inform decision-making.

1. Enhanced customer experience.

Today’s customers expect prompt and seamless service. The current standard for call centers is to answer 80% of calls in under 20 seconds. This is crucial because delays can lead to customer frustration and dissatisfaction, prompting them to turn to competitors or share negative feedback.

Beyond speed, customers also desire personalized service. They expect agents to recognize them, understand their history with the company, and offer solutions tailored to their specific needs. Without personalized support, 76% of users report dissatisfaction.

This is where CRM systems play a vital role, enabling both speed and personalization. With a centralized information repository, CRM platforms allow agents to quickly access relevant customer data. Incorporating CRM AI further enhances this capability, enabling agents to swiftly review customer histories, anticipate inquiries based on past interactions, and provide recommendations tailored to each customer’s current situation.

2. Improved agent productivity.

Agents require effective tools to perform their roles optimally, which includes seamless access to customer information. Without the right tools, customer satisfaction can decline. It’s crucial for business leaders to provide agents with next-generation solutions that enable efficient and accurate management of customer data and interactions. CRM solutions fulfill this need by consolidating customer information from various channels and systems into a single, easy-to-access interface.

3. Seamless omni-channel CRM integration

For call centers offering multiple communication options, CRM systems play a crucial role by consolidating data from various platforms—such as email, chat, social media, and SMS—into a single interface. Over 75% of call centers now support omnichannel communications. This trend is driven by modern customer expectations for seamless transitions between different channels without the need to repeat information or face inconsistent service. For example, a customer might engage via live chat one day and phone the next, expecting the agent to be aware of their identity, reason for contact, and the context of their concern.

CRM platforms are designed for easy integration across these channels, ensuring that regardless of whether a customer reaches out by phone, email, chat, social media, or SMS, agents have immediate access to the complete interaction history and relevant context.

4. Data-driven insights

Data-driven insights are essential for informing training, improving customer service, and more. Without them, business leaders are essentially operating without clear direction. Modern CRM platforms leverage AI to analyze extensive customer data in real-time, identifying patterns and trends, predicting customer behavior, and providing recommendations for personalized marketing strategies and service enhancements. Business leaders can access this information through an intuitive, centralized platform.

Key data points gathered by CRM systems include:

  • Customer interaction history: A comprehensive log of all customer touchpoints across various channels (e.g., phone calls, emails, chats, social media) with timestamps, interaction types, and content for detailed behavior and preference analysis.
  • Sales pipeline metrics: Quantitative data tracking each stage of the sales funnel, including lead sources, conversion rates, deal velocity, and projected revenue for accurate forecasting and sales strategy optimization.
  • Customer segmentation data: Classifications of customers based on demographics, purchasing history, behavior patterns, and engagement levels.
  • Customer lifetime value (CLV): A predictive calculation estimating the total revenue expected from a single customer throughout their relationship with the company.
  • Support ticket analytics: Metrics related to customer service interactions, such as the number of tickets opened and closed, average resolution time, first contact resolution rate, and customer satisfaction scores.

5. Enhanced team collaboration

A CRM platform offers a centralized platform where agents, supervisors, and other stakeholders can share information, communicate seamlessly, and coordinate their efforts. The CRM features that facilitate enhanced team collaboration include shared dashboards, real-time messaging, and document collaboration tools.

CRM systems come equipped with role-based access controls and collaborative workflows that streamline the management of intricate customer issues requiring insights from various departments. For instance, the support, engineering, and billing teams may be required to coordinate to resolve a technical support query. CRM solutions consolidate all pertinent information and communications into a single platform, facilitating seamless handoffs and synchronized responses among all teams.

6. Scalability and adaptability

Cloud-based call center CRMs grow as you do. Unlike traditional call centers that are often limited by their physical infrastructure and capacity, cloud-based CRM systems can scale dynamically to accommodate growing call volumes and geographic expansion without significant upfront investment in hardware. This adaptability ensures that businesses can efficiently handle increased customer interactions during peak periods or as they enter new markets.

Cloud-based scalability is also cost-effective. Call center CRM providers enable businesses to pay only for the resources they use, often billed on a subscription basis. Pay-on-demand models lead to substantial cost savings compared to maintaining and upgrading physical call center infrastructure—meaning companies can easily adjust their investment based on actual, real-time demand.

Choosing a CRM software: Features for call centers

No two call centers are the same. The best CRM platform for your operations will align with your own predetermined objectives and resource allocation. Yet, across the board, we’re seeing call centers of all types looking to adopt next-generation CRM features that—no matter the caller demographic—enhance engagement, streamline service delivery, and ultimately meet today’s customer needs.

These features include actionable reports, seamless integrations, centralized communications tools, and proficient omnichannel management capabilities.

Actionable reports

What are the metrics that each call center agent can draw on to make sure individual customers feel properly acknowledged?

  • Average handle time (AHT): Measures the average duration of a customer interaction, including talk time, hold time, and after-call work, helping to assess agent efficiency.
  • Customer satisfaction score (CSAT): Gauges the satisfaction level of customers with a specific interaction or overall service experience, typically obtained through post-interaction surveys.
  • First contact resolution (FCR): Indicates the percentage of customer issues resolved during the first interaction, a key metric for evaluating the effectiveness of customer service.
  • Net promoter score (NPS): Assesses customer loyalty by measuring the likelihood that a customer would recommend the company to others, derived from responses on a scale of 0 to 10.
  • Customer effort score (CES): Evaluates how much effort a customer has to exert to get their issue resolved, which can directly impact their overall satisfaction and loyalty.
  • Conversion rate: Tracks the percentage of contacts that result in a sale or specific desired outcome, useful for gauging the effectiveness of sales-oriented interactions.
  • Service level: Measures the percentage of calls answered within a certain timeframe.
  • Abandonment rate: Shows the rate at which customers disconnect the call before reaching an agent, indicating potential issues with wait times or call routing.

These data points are actionable as they provide specific, quantifiable insights that agents can use to enhance their interaction with customers. For instance, AHT allows agents to gauge the efficiency of their call handling. If AHT is high, agents can explore ways to resolve queries faster without sacrificing quality. Similarly, CSAT and NPS give direct feedback on how customers perceive their interactions. Agents can use this feedback to personalize their approach and address areas where customers may feel underserved.

As the customer effort score (CES) evaluates how easily customers can resolve their issues, lower scores indicate the need for agents to simplify processes or offer more direct solutions to common problems. By analyzing all metrics, call center managers can access actionable data that guides decisions on training, process improvements, and resource allocation.

Integrations with existing systems

There are two main methods for integrating your call center with a CRM system: native integrations and third-party integrations.

Native integrations involve pre-built connectors that allow for seamless connectivity directly within the CRM system without the need for external assistance. On the other hand, third-party integrations rely on APIs to link your contact center to the CRM, enabling connection with just a few clicks.

Generally speaking, native integrations tend to offer more reliability and speed, as they are specifically designed for the CRM system and reduce the complexity and potential issues associated with third-party middleware.

When evaluating CRM software for your call center, consider the following to ensure effective integration:

  • Compatibility: Check whether the CRM can integrate with your current software. This includes everything from your communication tools to data management systems.
  • Data synchronization: Ensure that the CRM can synchronize data across all platforms in real-time. This prevents data silos and ensures that all customer interactions are up-to-date and accessible to all agents.
  • Ease of implementation: Assess how easy it is to set up and maintain the CRM integration. Moreover, look for CRM providers that offer support for integration issues.
  • Customizability: Determine if the CRM allows for customizations that align with your specific call center workflows and processes.

Centralized communications tools

Centralized communications tools embedded within CRM systems transform call center operations by providing agents with a single, powerful interface for all customer interactions. This integration doesn’t just simplify the user experience; it amplifies the agent’s ability to deliver personalized service.

The centralized CRM communications features to look for include integrated multi-channel support (phone, email, chat, SMS), unified customer profiles, real-time data updates, customizable dashboards, automated routing of customer inquiries, sentiment analysis tools, and comprehensive interaction logs—all accessible from a single interface.

This extends to internal communications, too. Ensure your CRM of choice offers integrated team communication tools, role-based access control, the ability to assign and track support tickets, integrated knowledge bases for quick information retrieval, and real-time activity logs to monitor and optimize team performance.

Omnichannel management

Does your call center offer more than just phone-based interactions? If so, you’ll need a contact center CRM with strong omnichannel management capabilities that can seamlessly integrate and synchronize customer interactions across all platforms, including email, chat, social media, and mobile apps. This ensures that no matter how a customer chooses to contact your call center, their information and interaction history exist in a single customer view.

Traditionally speaking, call centers waste much time and resources on the data silos and fragmented customer interactions that result from using multiple, disconnected communication channels. A robust omnichannel contact center CRM eliminates these inefficiencies by providing a cohesive platform that captures and centralizes data from all touchpoints.

Creating customer delight: Webex Contact Center

Webex Contact Center seamlessly integrates with CRM systems and various communication channels by leveraging its cloud-native, microservices architecture. Its robust integration capacity enables call centers to manage customer interactions across voice, email, chat, and social media platforms within a single, unified interface.

Security and compliance are foundational to Webex Contact Center, featuring comprehensive measures such as data encryption in transit and at rest, role-based access controls, and adherence to industry standards like PCI DSS, HIPAA, and ISO27001. These protocols safeguard sensitive customer information and ensure regulatory compliance, providing peace of mind for both businesses and their clients.

Learn more about Webex Contact Center’s full range of solutions, including next-generation AI call center capabilities.

item.title: Introducing Internet Telephony Numbers for Webex Calling in India ...
item.content:encoded:
Cisco is excited to announce the availability of Internet Telephony Numbers for Webex Calling in India. This feature revolutionizes how businesses in India can implement cloud-based calling solutions by simplifying regulatory compliance, reducing costs, and enhancing flexibility for hybrid work. Here’s what this means for organizations in the region.

Restrictions of Fixed Line numbers

Webex Calling is available in India today with “Fixed Line” numbers. Indian Telecom regulations require customers to procure these Fixed Line numbers from an operator, along with direct connectivity (e.g. MPLS) which adds further cost.

There are also restrictions on Fixed Line numbers. For example, if a Fixed Line number is assigned to an office user, the user must be connected to the office network using a secure dedicated connection from home to make and receive calls. Users on fixed line numbers are not allowed to bypass the PSTN provider to reduce toll charges. For example, an incoming call to a Fixed Line number in Mumbai, may not be forwarded over VoIP to a user located in Chennai.

These limitations create financial and operational barriers for businesses looking to adopt modern, cloud-based communication systems, particularly in hybrid work environments.

The Solution: Internet Telephony Numbers

To address these challenges, we’re excited to introduce Internet Telephony Numbers for Webex Calling – a more flexible and cost-effective alternative. Key features include:

  • User experience: End users working from home can make and receive calls even when they are connected using an internet connection to their office network.
  • Internet Connectivity: Organizations can connect access devices (e.g., desk phones, Webex apps) to Webex Calling over the Internet, eliminating the need for private network connections.
  • No Toll Bypass Restrictions: Users with Internet Telephony numbers can make and receive calls anywhere in India without toll bypass concerns, for example they can forward a PSTN canner to another Webex Calling user anywhere in India.
  • Simplified Deployment: This solution is particularly appealing for small and medium businesses (SMBs) looking for affordable and easy-to-implement cloud calling. Additionally, businesses can easily expand in India by procuring Internet Telephony Numbers that work with basic internet access, and do not require direct connectivity (MPLS), which can be cumbersome and expensive to procure.

Impact for Businesses in India

With Internet Telephony numbers, organizations in India can significantly reduce costs by eliminating the need for expensive private network connections, making enterprise-grade Webex Calling solutions more affordable. This feature also enhances hybrid work by allowing users to connect to Webex Calling from any location within India using the Internet, enabling seamless remote and hybrid work setups. Additionally, it simplifies compliance with India’s telecom regulations through features like geolocation-based call blocking for users roaming outside the country, ensuring easy adherence to regulatory requirements.

How It Works

  • Administrators: Procure Internet Telephony numbers from your telecom provider and assign them to users, workspace devices, and features in Webex Calling locations in India.
  • End Users: Use Internet Telephony numbers as they would with fixed-line numbers. Users with Internet Telephony Numbers face no restrictions within India, and users travelling abroad cannot make PSTN calls while they are outside India.
  • Regulatory Compliance: Webex Calling integrates geolocation services to identify the user’s IP address and location, ensuring compliance with Telecommunication Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) guidelines.

A Game-Changer for Indian Businesses

The introduction of Internet Telephony numbers for Webex Calling makes enterprise-grade calling solutions more accessible and affordable for businesses in India. By reducing costs, simplifying compliance, and enabling hybrid work, Cisco continues to innovate and empower organizations in one of the world’s fastest-growing markets.
